commit_message:
Add collections path

Since we'll be installing collections into quickstart, we need to set
the ansible collections path correctly in the toci quickstart script.

Change-Id: I39c33da8af98ef01ddf020e4cdf96403bc0edc20
Related-Blueprint: tripleo-operator-ansible

commit_message:
Use py3 for CentOS

Unfortunatelly CentOS 7 do not have libvirt and guestfs libraries
for py3, so isntead of symlinking them, we have to install devel package
and build inside venv.

Change-Id: Ie678e44c2369347cf0816cbcc4269de8eba7b963

commit_message:
Stop service when app can't be started

uWSGI service can be showed as running even if it's unable to
find wsgi file. It will generate error like [1] and continue re-trying
To prevent this from happening, we should exit when app error occur

[1] `no python application found, check your startup logs for errors`

Change-Id: I24566df66caa651926b13891f00220bd8795bdb3

messages: [{'account_id': 14892, 'date': '2019-12-27 19:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14892, 'date': '2019-12-27 19:17:36.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bug/1856243 to bug/1856243-stable/train-stable/stein-stable/rocky'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-12-30 11:29:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-01-04 15:15:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-27 19:15:03.000000000', 'message': 'Fix "prev" link pagination for instances with identical timestamps

This patch resolves an issue with the "prev" link when instances
have identical "created_at" values. This can occur when creating
instance using the "min/max count" option. The reverse sort does not
work correctly as the server list returned from nova is not an exact
reverse as the forward sort. It looks like the combination of sort_keys
must be unique to ensure the forward and reverse pagination properly.
As a workaround 'uuid' (server ID) is added to 'sort_keys'.
In addition, 'display_name' is added before 'uuid' in 'sort_keys'
to list servers in the alphabetical order (which sounds natural).

Closes-Bug #1856243
Change-Id: I73234b2c69ce8ea648b4a9721abe4f5670031909
(cherry picked from commit 9637d733749d741d5aac3b89b92e100d32fbdbb0)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix "prev" link pagination for instances with identical timestamps

This patch resolves an issue with the "prev" link when instances
have identical "created_at" values. This can occur when creating
instance using the "min/max count" option. The reverse sort does not
work correctly as the server list returned from nova is not an exact
reverse as the forward sort. It looks like the combination of sort_keys
must be unique to ensure the forward and reverse pagination properly.
As a workaround 'uuid' (server ID) is added to 'sort_keys'.
In addition, 'display_name' is added before 'uuid' in 'sort_keys'
to list servers in the alphabetical order (which sounds natural).

Closes-Bug #1856243
Change-Id: I73234b2c69ce8ea648b4a9721abe4f5670031909
(cherry picked from commit 9637d733749d741d5aac3b89b92e100d32fbdbb0)

irrelevant failures, not rechecking because I'm tired of random errors here and there, look at the previous run to see these two green"}, {'account_id': 30523, 'date': '2020-01-02 07:33:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck

just trying my luck :]'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-02 08:05:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

yeah, this is a good way to check if it's your day for betting or not :-)"}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-02 09:23:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

we no wait enuff'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-02 09:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

and Dincer... no betting today ;-)'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-01-02 12:56:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Makes sense. Not sure what's going on with those ceph upgrade jobs."}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-02 16:09:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Makes sense. Not sure what's going on with those ceph upgrade jobs.

The "master" changes so the "slaves" might not be fully working or something ("" because it's really multi-master in case someone wonders)... Obviously I can't reproduce the failure locally... :-)'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-02 17:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So it looks like the "master" decides it lost connection to 2 other members and hence declares himself out of quorum (assuming the other 2 are quorum). The issue is random but somehow this change of "master" makes the problem more common. Due to how galera works, we should ideally do the following serially for each: stop mariadb, wait for its stop to be advertised, start it back, wait for its start to be advertised. Under normal circumstances we could limit ourselves to serializing at least the already-implemented part: stop/start and check local liveness.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-03 07:47:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

we really need a rewrite of this to use 3 phases + phase for the newly deployed'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-04 10:56:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

superseded by https://review.opendev.org/701010 (3 phases approach + separation of deploys and upgrades)'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-01 19:37:49.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Default to TLS in the functional test gate

OVN makes use of TLS for authorization and authentication of its
peers and it does not really make sense to deploy without it.

Let's reflect this fact in the functional tests.

TODO:

- Evaluate whether success of existing functional tests with TLS
  enabled for OVN is enough in itself or if additional TLS
  specific validation is required.

- Propose to Neutron repo as soon as the OVN-related tests pass
  there.

Change-Id: I07d930322791967a16b173d4c5009f60684ce6ad
Related-Bug: #1847032
Related-Bug: #1850160

commit_message:
[WIP] Default to TLS in the functional test gate

OVN makes use of TLS for authorization and authentication of its
peers and it does not really make sense to deploy without it.

Let's reflect this fact in the functional tests.

TODO:

- Evaluate whether success of existing functional tests with TLS
  enabled for OVN is enough in itself or if additional TLS
  specific validation is required.

- Propose to Neutron repo as soon as the OVN-related tests pass
  there.

Change-Id: I07d930322791967a16b173d4c5009f60684ce6ad
Related-Bug: #1847032
Related-Bug: #1850160

commit_message:
Fix error triggered by reading intergers as string from virtualbmc.conf

Add validation to fix error of "'<' not supported between
instances of 'str' and 'int'" when defining server_response_timeout
value in virtualbmc.conf. The error is trigger because the
config parameters from the configuration file are read as strings
and everything else assume that value is an integer (as the default of 5000).

The patch also include validations for server_spawn_wait and server_port to
check the values are valid integers.

Updates test_config.test_validate for test coverage

Task: 37947
Story: 2007066

Change-Id: Ie4e74585d8e14bd73e5e30b21b4dd7bd7d88f13d
Signed-off-by: William Caban <william.caban@gmail.com>

commit_message:
redfish-vmedia: correctly pass ipa-debug

The PXE/iPXE boot interfaces pass ipa-debug=1 when debugging is
enabled in ironic. The vmedia boot interface should do the same.

Change-Id: Ifd97eeebc95845a32c2d3ece513c25fdb52812d3
(cherry picked from commit 2e33669b4157cb3e55cd775f950981f059db7394)

commit_message:
Improve devstack script for vault plugin

- Clean up vault related things before starting new screen session
- Add the clean up functions in the cleanup stage

Change-Id: I6e291a975755491927a971b7c3bf97e5dabafa05

subject: Import directly from the inside of the ring module
messages:
[{'account_id': 597, 'date': '2020-01-04 01:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-04 01:31:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I agree, this seems perfectly harmless. I wish I could repro your trouble though -- for me, it's slow, but it imports:

 (py37) $ time python -c 'from swift.common.ring import Ring'
 
 real	0m0.532s
 user	0m0.471s
 sys	0m0.059s

Drilling down doesn't really help any:

 (py37) $ time python -c 'from swift.common.ring.ring import Ring'
 
 real	0m0.534s
 user	0m0.480s
 sys	0m0.052s

In fact, that slowness seems to affect swift code generally:

 (py37) $ time python -c 'from swift.common import utils'
 
 real	0m0.535s
 user	0m0.470s
 sys	0m0.062s

...if a bit unevenly:

 (py37) $ time python -c 'from swift import common'
 
 real	0m0.296s
 user	0m0.262s
 sys	0m0.031s

stdlib's *way* better, though, even when we gotta drill down:

 (py37) $ time python -c 'from urllib import parse'
 
 real	0m0.070s
 user	0m0.061s
 sys	0m0.008s

*shrug*"}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2020-01-04 03:47:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-04 01:14:54.000000000', 'message': 'Import directly from the inside of the ring module

An odd thing happened: when my code did only
"from swift.common.ring import Ring", and nothing else,
the interpreter looped on the CPU.

The import from the top of the ring module is our standard
protocol for Ring. It causes no problem in places like
container updater or list_endpoints.py. It is a big
mystery why it causes Python 3.7.3 to loop, and only
in specific circumstances.

But we noticed that the recursive import is unnecesasry
in this case, so an obviously harmless fix exists.

Change-Id: I7373bbb0a50d090d6becf141e5832f8ae98381a4
'}]
commit_message:
Import directly from the inside of the ring module

An odd thing happened: when my code did only
"from swift.common.ring import Ring", and nothing else,
the interpreter looped on the CPU.

The import from the top of the ring module is our standard
protocol for Ring. It causes no problem in places like
container updater or list_endpoints.py. It is a big
mystery why it causes Python 3.7.3 to loop, and only
in specific circumstances.

But we noticed that the recursive import is unnecesasry
in this case, so an obviously harmless fix exists.

Change-Id: I7373bbb0a50d090d6becf141e5832f8ae98381a4

[{'created': '2019-12-13 14:50:19.000000000', 'message': 'PowerMax Driver - retype attached replication fix

Fixes for retyping attached volumes when moving from
non-replicated to replication enabled volume type.
Cases fixed:
-Retype to metro replication with existing pairs.
-Retype to non-replicated after retyping to metro.
-Retype to asynchronous replication with existing pairs present.
-Delete attached volume with asynchronous replication after
attaching to an instance.

Change-Id: Ibbf04dedade6e85649ec702574ce51ce82fc8733
Closes-Bug: #1851371
(cherry picked from commit 49b941b83a3db3f9f561590887e174742f50cc2b)
'}]
commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - retype attached replication fix

Fixes for retyping attached volumes when moving from
non-replicated to replication enabled volume type.
Cases fixed:
-Retype to metro replication with existing pairs.
-Retype to non-replicated after retyping to metro.
-Retype to asynchronous replication with existing pairs present.
-Delete attached volume with asynchronous replication after
attaching to an instance.

Change-Id: Ibbf04dedade6e85649ec702574ce51ce82fc8733
Closes-Bug: #1851371
(cherry picked from commit 49b941b83a3db3f9f561590887e174742f50cc2b)

commit_message:
Make octavia reproducible

This is a forward of the patch attached to the Debian bug here:
https://bugs.debian.org/908222

Whilst working on the Reproducible Builds effort [0], we noticed
that octavia could not be built reproducibly.

This is because it embeds the hostname in the config file (which
also gets picked up in the documentation and the documentation
index files.)

 [0] https://reproducible-builds.org/

Change-Id: Ic290d733b2cd927f05a2becef3b3d9984d1b7a73

[{'created': '2020-01-03 16:53:42.000000000', 'message': '[stable] consume virtualbmc from pip packages

The virtualbmc master has dropped support for Python 2, breaking
stable CI jobs. Since we expect this to be a one-time breakage,
limit the existing stable branches to virtualbmc in upper-constraints
by removing it from required projects in the CI jobs.

Change-Id: I15464410c9e74b915a647bffbaac02770d15f6b2
(cherry picked from commit 7c993afb1f1a4389a5a7582925f6ff6a2e9b3b81)
'}]
commit_message:
[stable] consume virtualbmc from pip packages

The virtualbmc master has dropped support for Python 2, breaking
stable CI jobs. Since we expect this to be a one-time breakage,
limit the existing stable branches to virtualbmc in upper-constraints
by removing it from required projects in the CI jobs.

Change-Id: I15464410c9e74b915a647bffbaac02770d15f6b2
(cherry picked from commit 7c993afb1f1a4389a5a7582925f6ff6a2e9b3b81)

commit_message:
Allow ctlplane subnets in undercloud chrony acl rules

At present chronyd runs as client and can't be used as NTP server
by the overcloud nodes. It would be good to allow the ctlplane
subnets for it to be used by the overcloud.

Change-Id: If5911de750a284ae513b343daa4886bb2f547b29
Closes-Bug: #1858096
(cherry picked from commit 9e5c1103effd04979f5d1c1bf56416fd4816eb46)

[{'created': '2020-01-03 12:37:18.000000000', 'message': '[stable] consume virtualbmc from pip packages

The virtualbmc master has dropped support for Python 2, breaking
stable CI jobs. Since we expect this to be a one-time breakage,
limit the existing stable branches to virtualbmc in upper-constraints
by removing it from required projects in the CI jobs.

Change-Id: I15464410c9e74b915a647bffbaac02770d15f6b2
'}]
commit_message:
[stable] consume virtualbmc from pip packages

The virtualbmc master has dropped support for Python 2, breaking
stable CI jobs. Since we expect this to be a one-time breakage,
limit the existing stable branches to virtualbmc in upper-constraints
by removing it from required projects in the CI jobs.

Change-Id: I15464410c9e74b915a647bffbaac02770d15f6b2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2017-11-01 16:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26880, 'date': '2017-11-03 09:22:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

A quick feedback on this one. We have some requirements in our enterprise network (security, compliance, whatever) that doesn't allow us to use nsxv on vwmare but only DVS (Don't ask me why it's a fact).
With this patch i was finally able to have neutron running with dns-integration and now my zone is updated automatically as soon as i add a host in my network."}, {'account_id': 26880, 'date': '2017-11-04 23:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Forget last comment... was intended for vmware-nsx other review.'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2017-11-07 05:22:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

I don't like the idea of supporting various extensions. In the OSC experience, I just want the feature set to be supported. I would like to first see neutron supporting this in their core api first."}, {'account_id': 26880, 'date': '2017-11-07 08:48:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I fully understand your concern. My wish is to have dns-domain integrated in osc... some other past reviews already try to achieve it.... https://review.openstack.org/#/c/387617/... core reviewers seems to require at least some check/feedback to user if the backend extensions are not available.... 
So 2 options:
-We simply add this parameter and the user get a http error 400 if the backend extension is not available.
-We add a small check like it's implemented in this review."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2017-11-08 06:02:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Pierre I did bring up this patch in the Neutron pain point forum session https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Neutron-pain-points-Sydney

I think we're all in agreement that extended attributes are bad in general. Extended attributes make writing SDKs/clients difficult cause they all have to do exception handling everywhere. The same goes for these extended features in the API.

Micro-versions + capability discovery was brought up as an alternative. I'm not sure how that solves the problem either. Is the goal to create a dynamic CLI usage output? Just seems like not a good idea, and dns-domain is a good example of something that should just be in the Neutron core API to begin with. This patch is just furthering the problem down the line."}, {'account_id': 26880, 'date': '2017-11-08 09:58:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

Hello Mike,
I appreciate your explanation and the time you took to discuss it at the summit. It seems clear to me now (I'm just a newbie here). I'll abandon this review and update all related bug/wish on launchpad with the details you provided here. Thanks."}, {'account_id': 26880, 'date': '2017-11-08 12:53:35.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Extended attributes should not be implemented on OSC for now.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2017-12-02 03:05:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Pierre I did bring up this patch in the Neutron pain point forum
 > session https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Neutron-pain-points-Sydney
 > 
 > I think we're all in agreement that extended attributes are bad in
 > general. Extended attributes make writing SDKs/clients difficult
 > cause they all have to do exception handling everywhere. The same
 > goes for these extended features in the API.
 > 
 > Micro-versions + capability discovery was brought up as an
 > alternative. I'm not sure how that solves the problem either. Is
 > the goal to create a dynamic CLI usage output? Just seems like not
 > a good idea, and dns-domain is a good example of something that
 > should just be in the Neutron core API to begin with. This patch is
 > just furthering the problem down the line.

As per line 42, my overdue feedback: everything in neutron is strictly speaking an extension, and some attributes are always present by virtue of config tricks (e.g. port security is always present in devstack, and tagging, timestamps are loaded by default at runtime). As for DNS, the API is implemented internally to the neutron repo therefore should be considered as core as the routers or security groups. For this reason, I'd say that this patch deserved to be restored and tweaked just to accept dns-domain the same way port-security is accepted."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2017-12-02 03:07:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> I don't like the idea of supporting various extensions. In the OSC
 > experience, I just want the feature set to be supported. I would
 > like to first see neutron supporting this in their core api first.

This is technically in the core API, and to make this patch mergeable perhaps we can get rid of the logic that sends an error that checks for the presence of the attribute."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-12-04 03:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Restored'}, {'account_id': 26880, 'date': '2017-12-04 07:40:56.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Pierre Hanselmann <pierre.hanselmann@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 26880, 'date': '2017-12-04 07:42:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> Removed Code-Review-1 by Pierre Hanselmann <pierre.hanselmann@gmail.com>

Ok so... Could a core commiter state clearly on what is expected on this patch? I would gladly updated it as long as everyone agree on the behavior.
Do we just remove the checks on the extension availability? Let me know...'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-12-25 04:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Pierre, sorry for late.

OSC team considers the networking API defined in neutron-lib repository (and available in the API reference) as the official networking API. Attribute extensions for resources supported by OSC (i.e., the resources supported by "neutron" repo) are accepted by the OSC repo. (Note that some experimental resources added by "neutron" repo (like trunk or logging) are supported by neutronclient OSC plugin.)

Considering this, this patch is acceptable.

The keyword "extension" is confusing. At now, all resources except network/subnet/port are implemented using the "extension" mechanism from the historical reason. We need to revisit the current situation, but in a short term solution (1 or 2 releases) we consider all extensions defined in the neutron-lib repo are official.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-02-18 03:00:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:18:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Add dns-domain support to Network object

Add "dns-domain" parameter to Network class. Also check
backend extensions and send an error message in case of
an argument (like dns-domain) is sent and the extension is
missing (dns-integration in this case).

Change-Id: I7303658c27d9b9f2d8381ccea0b29e96909cab54
Closes-Bug: 1633214
Partial-Bug: 1547736

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-13 14:02:43.000000000', 'message': 'Fix list zones updated at same time

In case multiple zones have the same update timestamp (updated_at) the
UI did not show any zone and a JS console listed an error
"Error: [ngRepeat:dupes] Duplicates in a repeater are not allowed."
To fix it addTimestampIds needs to get the correct parameter order,
i.e. pass the name of the ID column before the timestamp column name.

Closes-Bug: 1734601

Change-Id: Ib91f873e8f21b71a71b1684317db276b72ae8014
(cherry picked from commit c6d53e4f8a36046c55e08272bf3859d5cb4c7c44)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix list zones updated at same time

In case multiple zones have the same update timestamp (updated_at) the
UI did not show any zone and a JS console listed an error
"Error: [ngRepeat:dupes] Duplicates in a repeater are not allowed."
To fix it addTimestampIds needs to get the correct parameter order,
i.e. pass the name of the ID column before the timestamp column name.

Closes-Bug: 1734601

Change-Id: Ib91f873e8f21b71a71b1684317db276b72ae8014
(cherry picked from commit c6d53e4f8a36046c55e08272bf3859d5cb4c7c44)

messages: [{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-01-03 14:35:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-01-03 14:41:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-01-03 18:26:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-03 14:35:27.000000000', 'message': "Do not configure Hiera and Hieradata in Ansible check mode

When deploying TripleO in dry-run (Ansible check mode to True); we don't
need to generate the Hieradata ; it's expecting actual files
and data; which doesn't exist in check mode.

Let's just skip the whole role if the check mode is used.

Change-Id: I1f54878ef6a59ab772e6c2f75493efb2eb45cf3a
(cherry picked from commit f1e1f4ba0471c47982cc6da9e5aa304d61adbee5)
"}]
commit_message:
Do not configure Hiera and Hieradata in Ansible check mode

When deploying TripleO in dry-run (Ansible check mode to True); we don't
need to generate the Hieradata ; it's expecting actual files
and data; which doesn't exist in check mode.

Let's just skip the whole role if the check mode is used.

Change-Id: I1f54878ef6a59ab772e6c2f75493efb2eb45cf3a
(cherry picked from commit f1e1f4ba0471c47982cc6da9e5aa304d61adbee5)

commit_message:
Add bandit check to osh-infra

This change adds a non-voting bandit check to openstack-helm-infra
similar to what is ran in the openstack-helm repo.

This check will be made voting in a future change once the current
failures are addressed.

Similarly this check will be modified in a future change to
only be ran when affected python files are changed.

Change-Id: I177940f7b050fbe8882d298628c458bbd935ee89

commit_message:
Restore test_minbw_allocation_placement in nova-next job

This test was accidentally removed via [1] so we restored it via [2],
but that fell afoul of the related bug so we re-disabled it via [3].
Once the dependency merges, we should be able to re-restore it.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/683988/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697180/
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697491/

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/682964
Change-Id: I9c11f25307b6b3859522775bb8172b901b468d79
Related-Bug: #1854993

messages:
[{'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-12-11 18:16:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-12-11 18:32:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-12-11 18:32:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Based off of feedback, I lowered this from 100 to 50 to accommodate deployments with a small Undercloud.'}, {'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2019-12-12 08:07:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Based off of feedback, I lowered this from 100 to 50 to accommodate
 > deployments with a small Undercloud.

what should be the ratio between forks and available cores?'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-12-12 17:00:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Finding the optimal number of forks is somewhat complicated. Based on my previous work with AWX, we would recommend using anywhere between 10 forks per vCPU and 100 forks per 4GB RAM. For example, 2 vCPUs and 4GB RAM the suggested fork size would be somewhere between 20 and 100. It depends on whether our tasks are CPU or RAM bound. From my recent scale testing I'm more inclined to say we are RAM bound. My main concern is finding a good default balance that works in production and CI."}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-12-16 15:02:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Upon further testing, I found that Ansible processes are normally using 100% of each vCPU so they are actually CPU-bound. With our recommendation of 4 vCPUs for the Undercloud, the optimal forks is 40. Given that not everything is CPU-bound, I think it is okay to bump it up to 50. This sets are forks to x2 than it was before which should provide a nice out-of-the-box deployment time boost.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-12-16 15:55:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-12-16 21:43:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2019-12-17 07:40:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23811, 'date': '2019-12-17 12:31:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-12-17 13:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Yes, increasing forks has been tested (using 110 forks on a 4 vCPU and 16GB Undercloud with deploying a 400+ node Overcloud). This especially helps out in situations where there is an `include_*` task. That appears to only run on the number of hosts/forks specified before moving onto the next set of hosts.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-12-17 18:33:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

check-rdo'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-12-17 19:05:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-12-19 14:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-12-23 15:06:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Default to 50 Ansible forks.

During the initial Overcloud deployment, tasks will be ran on 50
hosts at a time now instead of 25. This allows for a faster
deployment of a large number of Overcloud nodes.

Change-Id: Idf0351dbc05bb63ae180e61beb9e7f933dc6fa31
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-18 18:55:15.000000000', 'message': 'Add a default network when creating a server

If a new server is created without defining a network, Nova will
retrieve the available networks for the corresponding project. In case
of having more than one network, Nova raises the exception
"NetworkAmbiguous", informing that in case of multiple networks found,
one must be selected in the call.

This error has been detected in "ServersNegativeTestJSON" test cases.

Change-Id: I71333a45982fc0b6b155d68e96640a9db3d41e4a
Closes-Bug: #1844568
'}, {'created': '2019-09-19 08:16:26.000000000', 'message': 'Add a default network when creating a server

commit_message:
Add a default network when creating a server

If a new server is created without defining a network, Nova will
retrieve the available networks for the corresponding project. In case
of having more than one network, Nova raises the exception
"NetworkAmbiguous", informing that in case of multiple networks found,
one must be selected in the call.

This error has been detected in "ServersNegativeTestJSON" test cases.

Change-Id: I71333a45982fc0b6b155d68e96640a9db3d41e4a
Closes-Bug: #1844568

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-18 20:30:11.000000000', 'message': 'Add Keycloak setup to featureset039

featureset039 is primarily used when TLS everywhere, novajoin and IPA
are needed. We want to round out this functionality with support for
federated authentication by installing the Keycloak IdP on the
supplemental node. The keycloak-setup role is being added in
tripleo-quickstart-extras as a consequence those patches appear
elsewhere in a different repository.

This patch adds the necessary configuration parameters to
featureset039 to invoke the keycloak-setup role in
tripleo-quickstart-extras and adds a dependency in
quickstart-extras-requirements.txt on an Ansible role
(nkinder.keycloak) used to install Keycloak.

Partial-Bug: 1836415

commit_message:
Add Keycloak setup to featureset039

featureset039 is primarily used when TLS everywhere, novajoin and IPA
are needed. We want to round out this functionality with support for
federated authentication by installing the Keycloak IdP on the
supplemental node. The keycloak-setup role is being added in
tripleo-quickstart-extras as a consequence those patches appear
elsewhere in a different repository.

This patch adds the necessary configuration parameters to
featureset039 to invoke the keycloak-setup role in
tripleo-quickstart-extras and adds a dependency in
quickstart-extras-requirements.txt on an Ansible role
(nkinder.keycloak) used to install Keycloak.

Partial-Bug: 1836415

Change-Id: I59eaa2dfe7b5a3a16be18ec5d3cc03f1e68a2661
Signed-off-by: John Dennis <jdennis@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix ansible docker support task

Removes become: and become_user: when including another role (that
already defines become: true and become_user: root)

Fixes an error occurring in the gates:
ERROR! 'become_user' is not a valid attribute for a IncludeRole

Change-Id: I362eefbe5b09ad64e97b3b541d07db2e6b990613

commit_message:
Use "name" argument for include_role

Switch to using the name argument for the name of the role for the
include_role module. While the "role" argument may have worked at one
time (or still works), it's no longer documented as an option for this
module by ansible:

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/include_role_module.html

Change-Id: I22617a966f4f84df3fed5274ad1937faa10c7f4e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-07 19:44:53.000000000', 'message': 'Rollback the volume_types table when failed to update quota_usages

We create a new volume based on a volume type, then update the volume
type name to a new name of 255 characters in length.
When updating the volume type table, the quota_usages table is updated
synchronously. If DB error occurs in the quota_usages table, we need to
roll back the volume types table.Otherwise, when the volume is deleted,
the information of the quota_usages table will not be updated.

Closes-bug: #1802430
Related-Bug: #1608849

Change-Id: I040ccde7f04ae39258afd9b7322c939c8d796bde
(cherry picked from commit c34e42af75b7b31adab7060fc2bd6ddfcab92bf5)
'}]
commit_message:
Rollback the volume_types table when failed to update quota_usages

We create a new volume based on a volume type, then update the volume
type name to a new name of 255 characters in length.
When updating the volume type table, the quota_usages table is updated
synchronously. If DB error occurs in the quota_usages table, we need to
roll back the volume types table.Otherwise, when the volume is deleted,
the information of the quota_usages table will not be updated.

Closes-bug: #1802430
Related-Bug: #1608849

Change-Id: I040ccde7f04ae39258afd9b7322c939c8d796bde
(cherry picked from commit c34e42af75b7b31adab7060fc2bd6ddfcab92bf5)

commit_message:
Add 'volume_attachment' to volume expected attributes

'volume_attachment' is a frequently used attribute when
listing volumes inside or outside cinder, considering
it already has been loaded from database [1], this patch
adds it to volume's expected attributes to improve
performance.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/0652085f23ba22f0a6335726d9f0f7018d4662ea/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L1926

Change-Id: I3be3c99f9317726fa3182f750b27690da3cdab83
(cherry picked from commit af66bce67638626e9c32f1ab75d1d67c8984b1b6)

[{'created': '2019-12-11 22:27:24.000000000', 'message': 'PowerMax Driver - Volume group delete failure

1. Volume group deletion failed after a group snapshot had been created
on and deleted from it. This fix eliminates the "cannot use the device for
the function because it is a Copy Session source" on cleanup.
2. Fix to update the metadata correctly for a generic group.

Change-Id: I558e9e67e427b40708220046eef953cb09ea4917
Closes-Bug: #1853589
(cherry picked from commit 27a5c58bdd87514a100517fadb345084b4d37da2)

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Volume group delete failure

1. Volume group deletion failed after a group snapshot had been created
on and deleted from it. This fix eliminates the "cannot use the device for
the function because it is a Copy Session source" on cleanup.
2. Fix to update the metadata correctly for a generic group.

Change-Id: I558e9e67e427b40708220046eef953cb09ea4917
Closes-Bug: #1853589
(cherry picked from commit 27a5c58bdd87514a100517fadb345084b4d37da2)

commit_message:
remove networking-ovs-dpdk legacy job

As part of moveing networking-ovs-dpdk to run tests
with python 3 only we are removing the legacy job
definition and replacing it with a zuul v3 native
job. This change removes the
legacy-tempest-dsvm-networking-ovs-dpdk job definition
and playbooks from this repo.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701046/1
Change-Id: Ib4b443fd413722c3b2f92920222691fecd572334

commit_message:
Allow ctlplane subnets in undercloud chrony acl rules

At present chronyd runs as client and can't be used as NTP server
by the overcloud nodes. It would be good to allow the ctlplane
subnets for it to be used by the overcloud.

Change-Id: If5911de750a284ae513b343daa4886bb2f547b29
Closes-Bug: #1858096

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-03 16:46:33.000000000', 'message': 'Remove networking-ovs-dpdk jobs

This change removes the python jobs template
and experimental job so that they can be managed
in repo.

This jobs adds the publish-to-pypi to allow future releases
to automatically be published if we choose to make them.
networking-ovs-dpdk currently uses a branch only releases
mode as required since it primary function is to provide a devstack
plugin that is generally version independent.

Change-Id: Ie7238a742005c38e2f910615175bfe7ef2d55622
'}]
commit_message:
Remove networking-ovs-dpdk jobs

This change removes the python jobs template
and experimental job so that they can be managed
in repo.

This jobs adds the publish-to-pypi to allow future releases
to automatically be published if we choose to make them.
networking-ovs-dpdk currently uses a branch only releases
mode as required since it primary function is to provide a devstack
plugin that is generally version independent.

Change-Id: Ie7238a742005c38e2f910615175bfe7ef2d55622

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-03 06:30:33.000000000', 'message': 'Task: 37947
Story: 2007066

Add validation to fix error of "'<' not supported between
instances of 'str' and 'int'" when defining server_response_timeout
value in virtualbmc.conf. The error is trigger because the
config parameters from the configuration file are read as strings
and everything else assume that value is an integer (as the default of 5000).

The patch also include validations for server_spawn_wait and server_port to
check the values are valid integers.

Updates  test_config.test_validate

Change-Id: Id6bf557c35440768cf3563c4809279beca31ad86
Signed-off-by: William Caban <william.caban@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Task: 37947
Story: 2007066

Add validation to fix error of "'<' not supported between
instances of 'str' and 'int'" when defining server_response_timeout
value in virtualbmc.conf. The error is trigger because the
config parameters from the configuration file are read as strings
and everything else assume that value is an integer (as the default of 5000).

The patch also include validations for server_spawn_wait and server_port to
check the values are valid integers.

Updates  test_config.test_validate

Change-Id: Id6bf557c35440768cf3563c4809279beca31ad86
Signed-off-by: William Caban <william.caban@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add '--quiet' switch

Quiet option turns off all image build logs above CRITICAL level. Handy
for checking build/push queue.

Change-Id: I9d49c9e6851341c084673ef2946acf4490c3ae8b

those who want to enable the neutron logging framework
(https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/rocky/admin/config-logging.html).
* Add variable "enable_neutron_log" that is used as other service
plugins variables in roles/neutron/defaults/main.yml.

local_output_log_base for the network openvswitch-agent.ini section.

Implements: neutron-log-service-plugin
'}]
commit_message:
Add ability to use the neutron logging framework

* Enables the use of the "log" service plugins for
those who want to enable the neutron logging framework
(https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/rocky/admin/config-logging.html).
* Add variable "enable_neutron_log" that is used as other service
plugins variables in roles/neutron/defaults/main.yml.
* Add variable to configure rate_limit, burst_limit and
local_output_log_base for the network openvswitch-agent.ini section.

Change-Id: Ia40c3685d6f173cc1fb977886f655664fd0d4521
Implements: neutron-log-service-plugin

commit_message:
Fix quoting for PYTHONWARNINGS

The fix for 1854868 introduced double quoting for the PYTHONWARNINGS
variable which leads to a message about an Invalid -W option being
displayed.

Closes-Bug: #1858113
(cherry picked from commit 45ab26770cff0c5672c8924ae93386b1e881b31b)

commit_message:
Fix quoting for PYTHONWARNINGS

The fix for 1854868 introduced double quoting for the PYTHONWARNINGS
variable which leads to a message about an Invalid -W option being
displayed.

Change-Id: I6a9b2704a9c6c7c1c9903532a5423408ede8ffc9
Closes-Bug: #1858113
(cherry picked from commit 45ab26770cff0c5672c8924ae93386b1e881b31b)

commit_message:
Add ability to specify timeout for ssh tries via rally config

  To be able to use boot_run_command_delete scenario with
  operating systems with long initialization or just be able to
  measure "ready_to_ssh" time let's make timeout for reaching ssh
  connection configurable.

Change-Id: I173063004087bf5a4ac1e07b7b405b3b1a118376

commit_message:
Add a feature support matrix test for grenade subnode

test-features.sh wasn't testing anything for subnodes
so this adds a subnode feature support matrix test for
grenade. It also highlights that the grenade config
is applied to all nodes regardless of role so a TODO
is added to test_matrix.py in case someone needs to make
that per-role, per-config service override support at
some point (hopefully that never really happens and all
jobs are moved to zuulv3 by that point).

Change-Id: I485d76c1db5c3a4363c3e26fea204cc7782887f3

commit_message:
CentOS 8: work around mod_ssl certificate issue

CentOS 8 has an issue with mod_ssl which produces an invalid Apache
configuration in /etc/httpd/conf.d/ssl.conf. This causes the following
error on startup:

SSLCertificateFile: file '/etc/pki/tls/certs/localhost.crt' does not exist or is empty

Work around this by generating certificates manually.

Partially-Implements: blueprint centos-rhel-8

Change-Id: Id8bcefa3527575ba72fe37013787ba716e435ac8

commit_message:
Do not configure Hiera and Hieradata in Ansible check mode

When deploying TripleO in dry-run (Ansible check mode to True); we don't
need to generate the Hieradata ; it's expecting actual files
and data; which doesn't exist in check mode.

Let's just skip the whole role if the check mode is used.

Change-Id: I1f54878ef6a59ab772e6c2f75493efb2eb45cf3a

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-20 00:38:52.000000000', 'message': 'SSC.disks_sizes_bytes handle CapacityBytes is None

In the open ocean, a Redfish service can return a SimpleStorage resource
containing a Device property with its CapacityBytes property set to
null. According to the Distributed Management Task Force (DMTF) schema
for SimpleStorage, the type of CapacityBytes can be either integer or
null [1].

The Dell integrated Dell Remote Access Controller (iDRAC) 9 running
Lifecycle Controller firmware version 3.30.30.30 returns that for a Dell
EMC PowerEdge R740xd containing a Dell HBA 330 12Gbps SAS Host Bus
Adapter Controller (non-RAID), MiniCard (HBA 330 Mini) [2]. The HBA 330
Mini firmware version is 16.17.00.03.

The same was observed against an R740xd running Lifecycle Controller
firmware version 3.34.34.34.

This changes the SimpleStorageCollection.disks_size_bytes property to
process only Disks with CapacityByes not set to None.

[1] https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/SimpleStorage.v1_2_3.json
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ironic/%23openstack-ironic.2019-12-11.log.html#t2019-12-11T07:24:17

Change-Id: I57a0074a7f6c4495e7c73a00c87675ea87fdb6e8
Story: 2006918
Task: 37567
'}]
commit_message:
SSC.disks_sizes_bytes handle CapacityBytes is None

In the open ocean, a Redfish service can return a SimpleStorage resource
containing a Device property with its CapacityBytes property set to
null. According to the Distributed Management Task Force (DMTF) schema
for SimpleStorage, the type of CapacityBytes can be either integer or
null [1].

The Dell integrated Dell Remote Access Controller (iDRAC) 9 running
Lifecycle Controller firmware version 3.30.30.30 returns that for a Dell
EMC PowerEdge R740xd containing a Dell HBA 330 12Gbps SAS Host Bus
Adapter Controller (non-RAID), MiniCard (HBA 330 Mini) [2]. The HBA 330
Mini firmware version is 16.17.00.03.

The same was observed against an R740xd running Lifecycle Controller
firmware version 3.34.34.34.

This changes the SimpleStorageCollection.disks_size_bytes property to
process only Disks with CapacityByes not set to None.

[1] https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/SimpleStorage.v1_2_3.json
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ironic/%23openstack-ironic.2019-12-11.log.html#t2019-12-11T07:24:17

Change-Id: I57a0074a7f6c4495e7c73a00c87675ea87fdb6e8
Story: 2006918
Task: 37567

commit_message:
Update master for stable/train

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/train.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/train.

Change-Id: I5807327737707a7c1057aa5b384c212d96faf7e0
Sem-Ver: feature

messages:
[{'account_id': 30933, 'date': '2019-09-04 15:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-09-04 15:23:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30933, 'date': '2019-09-20 07:30:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 30933, 'date': '2020-01-03 13:39:45.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Added `get_raw_image_mb()`

The `get_raw_image_mb()` function tries to query
`qemu check` for a potentially compressed image
and tries to compute the raw image size to be once
decompressed.

If the above trick does not work out for one reason
or another, the `get_raw_image_mb()` function returns
just the virtual_size of the image being queried.

Story: 1750515
Task: 24399
Change-Id: Id0229ac0270c0505ac6f1b5b5e4fe7ad719e830c

[{'created': '2019-10-04 12:29:21.000000000', 'message': "build: prioritize images by amount of children

When Kolla builds are done on multiple threads machines (like 40-200 on
aarch64) build can be stuck while building childless images while those
with several children are kept in a queue.

This change gives priority to those with children so build machine gets
better saturation.

New queue looks simple: 'base' gets built and 'openstack-base' build
starts. With other 2nd level images it can give us multiple tasks to
keep machine busy. Once 'openstack-base' finishes we get lot of 3rd
level build tasks to handle.

Change-Id: Ic8e648be12defcaf4ea96d154b683fcc39c72bd4
"}]
commit_message:
build: prioritize images by amount of children

When Kolla builds are done on multiple threads machines (like 40-200 on
aarch64) build can be stuck while building childless images while those
with several children are kept in a queue.

This change gives priority to those with children so build machine gets
better saturation.

New queue looks simple: 'base' gets built and 'openstack-base' build
starts. With other 2nd level images it can give us multiple tasks to
keep machine busy. Once 'openstack-base' finishes we get lot of 3rd
level build tasks to handle.

Change-Id: Ic8e648be12defcaf4ea96d154b683fcc39c72bd4

[{'created': '2019-12-20 19:44:35.000000000', 'message': "Disable c-bak and etcd3 in grenade jobs

Grenade only runs tempest smoke tests and there are no
cinder-backup service related smoke tests in the main
tempest repo so running the c-bak service on the primary
and subnode (in multinode jobs) is just a waste of resources
since it's not used in testing.

Similarly, etcd3 is really only interesting for cinder in
a multinode job but in grenade multinode jobs etcd3 is not
enabled on the subnode, so only the primary node cinder
services are configured to use etcd3, so again it's a waste
of resources.

There is a theory that bug 1844929 is failing primarily on
OVH nodes because they aggressively restrict iops so we're
running into swap issues [1]. Freeing up more resources on
the nodes used in grenade jobs might alleviate some of that
swap pressure.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010506.html

Similarly, etcd3 is really only interesting for cinder in
a multinode job but in grenade multinode jobs etcd3 is not
enabled on the subnode, so only the primary node cinder
services are configured to use etcd3, so again it's a waste

There is a theory that bug 1844929 is failing primarily on
OVH nodes because they aggressively restrict iops so we're
running into swap issues [1]. Freeing up more resources on
the nodes used in grenade jobs might alleviate some of that
swap pressure.

To do this using the feature test matrix in devstack-gate
the test_matrix.py script has to be updated such that
services can be added/removed per config rather than per
feature because otherwise grenade says it wants cinder but
cannot remove cinder-specific services like c-bak.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010506.html

Change-Id: Ide146793053ae6b62f93a5af45c6130a21514e87

commit_message:
Disable c-bak and etcd3 in grenade jobs

Grenade only runs tempest smoke tests and there are no
cinder-backup service related smoke tests in the main
tempest repo so running the c-bak service on the primary
and subnode (in multinode jobs) is just a waste of resources
since it's not used in testing.

Similarly, etcd3 is really only interesting for cinder in
a multinode job but in grenade multinode jobs etcd3 is not
enabled on the subnode, so only the primary node cinder
services are configured to use etcd3, so again it's a waste
of resources.

There is a theory that bug 1844929 is failing primarily on
OVH nodes because they aggressively restrict iops so we're
running into swap issues [1]. Freeing up more resources on
the nodes used in grenade jobs might alleviate some of that
swap pressure.

To do this using the feature test matrix in devstack-gate
the test_matrix.py script has to be updated such that
services can be added/removed per config rather than per
feature because otherwise grenade says it wants cinder but
cannot remove cinder-specific services like c-bak.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010506.html

Change-Id: Ide146793053ae6b62f93a5af45c6130a21514e87
Related-Bug: #1844929

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-20 10:39:27.000000000', 'message': 'Close ssh client after executing a command

Each time ssh.Client.exec_command is called, _get_ssh_connection creates
a new SSHClient instance.
If this instance is not closed after command execution, it might cause a
shortage of resources on the host (many open sockets, and dropbear
processes in a cirros VM).

This commit closes ssh client after processing the remote command.

Closes-Bug: #1853264

Change-Id: If77f401d6d4a1282ce31a31bbd8827db34690e52
'}]
commit_message:
Close ssh client after executing a command

Each time ssh.Client.exec_command is called, _get_ssh_connection creates
a new SSHClient instance.
If this instance is not closed after command execution, it might cause a
shortage of resources on the host (many open sockets, and dropbear
processes in a cirros VM).

This commit closes ssh client after processing the remote command.

Closes-Bug: #1853264

Change-Id: If77f401d6d4a1282ce31a31bbd8827db34690e52

commit_message:
Catch exceptions when processing subnets

We should do a better job indicating that there is invalid data in the
extra subnets that can be defined. This change catches exceptions that
occur when generating the inspection subnet data.

Change-Id: I175ff32ba5e5a271741349794cf28f1e58c50d6a
Closes-Bug: #1857057
(cherry picked from commit e970ca3cdf861b0e4d63cc8be3468bd52e775b01)

Change-Id: I67ca5956a44c3ee908e21dcf3b476e2c6c5c7f9e
Closes-Bug: #1857012
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
image_uploader: handle when an image has null labels

If an image inspect returns empty Labels, set the labels to an empty
dictionary.

Change-Id: I67ca5956a44c3ee908e21dcf3b476e2c6c5c7f9e
Closes-Bug: #1857012
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix quoting for PYTHONWARNINGS

The fix for 1854868 introduced double quoting for the PYTHONWARNINGS
variable which leads to a message about an Invalid -W option being
displayed.

Change-Id: I6a9b2704a9c6c7c1c9903532a5423408ede8ffc9
Closes-Bug: #1858113
(cherry picked from commit 45ab26770cff0c5672c8924ae93386b1e881b31b)

commit_message:
Add installation doc of tricircle work with container

1.What is the problem ?
  1) Lack of installation doc for multi-region container management.

2.What is the solution for the problem?
  1) Use zun component to provide container computation and use kuryr component to provide container network.In a word, make zun and kuryr compatible with tricircle.

Change-Id: I7dd2ee04409eb20f2e4ad1e919d13cda1f7775a5
Signed-off-by: XuShimin <948026069@qq.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-22 11:06:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix loading and retrieving network_segment_ranges
 data from neutron db with context from wsgi pipeline

Since Stein version neutron introduce network-segment-ranges
before network created, while somefunctions in the current neutron
retrieving data from network_segment_ranges db with fake context,
this may result error just as "oslo_db.exception.DBNonExistentTable:
(sqlite3.OperationalError) no such table: network_segment_ranges"
error from outer project using neutron api.

This patch fix the problem loading data from
network_segment_ranges table with context from wsgi pipeline

commit_message:
Fix loading and retrieving network_segment_ranges
data from neutron db with context from wsgi pipeline

Since Stein version neutron introduce network-segment-ranges
before network created, while some functions in the current neutron
retrieving data from network_segment_ranges db with fake context,
this may result error just as "oslo_db.exception.DBNonExistentTable:
(sqlite3.OperationalError) no such table: network_segment_ranges"
error from outer project using neutron api.

This patch fix the problem loading data from
network_segment_ranges table with context from wsgi pipeline
refer: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1821567

signed-off-by:  zhangchi <zhangchi@szzt.com.cn>
co-Authored-By: tangzhuo <ztang@hnu.edu.cn>
Change-Id: If8a51efb14c2c253b2dde36cc63c9d661c6d1773

commit_message:
Force arp_responder to True when DVR and tunneling enabled

After [1] and [2], the ARP responder needs to be enabled
if DVR and tunneling are enabled or ARP will not work. If
it is False we will log a message and force it to True.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/651905/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/653883/

Change-Id: I934062c970effe5194056b0786f84f3246850701
Related-bug: #1774459

commit_message:
Catch exceptions when processing subnets

We should do a better job indicating that there is invalid data in the
extra subnets that can be defined. This change catches exceptions that
occur when generating the inspection subnet data.

Closes-Bug: #1857057

commit_message:
Fix quoting for PYTHONWARNINGS

The fix for 1854868 introduced double quoting for the PYTHONWARNINGS
variable which leads to a message about an Invalid -W option being
displayed.

Change-Id: I6a9b2704a9c6c7c1c9903532a5423408ede8ffc9
Closes-Bug: #1858113

commit_message:
Add support for RDO CentOS8 repos and run CentOS8 jobs

Initially these jobs will be running as non-voting,
once stabilized will be moved to voting.

RDO with CentOS8 has moved to component based repos[1],
where for each component have it's own repo, the list
of component can grow/shrink with time so instead of
using base path to configure repo, pull repo files
directly and adjust proxy.

[1] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/22394/

Change-Id: I1de859f29c933d895fb5cd2b7f1897517e11385c

subject: Use less responses from handoffs
messages:
[{'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-12-20 20:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-12-20 20:34:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-12-23 16:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

This is related to Ia832e9bab13167948f01bc50aa8a61974ce189fb

Once we dropped the 404s we have some fail in place clusters where the 507s would "overwhelm" the primary responses and it was impossible to get 404 response!!!

error limiting made it somewhat sporadic - but this changed cleaned it up.

I'm not sure exactly how the bug report should read - there's some questionable quorum calculation going in best_response -'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-23 20:03:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Should we drop 5xx *all the time*, even from primaries?

I guess the downside would be that logging for 507, 507, 507, 404, 404, 404 (for example) would make it seem like we didn't make *any* backend requests...

On the whole, seems pretty reasonable given how we currently decide quorum!"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-01-02 18:04:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

commit message should reference bug # (which I don't have handy right now)"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-01-02 19:20:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-01-02 19:20:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

I think this is probably fine'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-02 22:15:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

I have a hard time imagining how this would be a *bad* idea...

FWIW, I tried

* a few different combinations of GETs, PUTs, POSTs, and DELETEs,
* with no object info, data files, and tombstones,
* with disks error-limited and not, but always with a bunch of crap unmounted.

About the only thing that still felt funny was a situation where I'd have nothing on disk and two primaries unmounted, so proxy would see 404, 507, 507. It'll dig into handoffs for another 404 (which gets thrown out), and return a 503 to the client -- makes sense enough, I suppose. But if you *keep asking for it*, those primaries get error limited and it flips to a 404!

It works out better when there's a tombstone on disk -- even if only the one primary knew about it, our fail-in-place logic should mean replication will get it to the first available handoff "soon-ish". Since it'll have a timestamp, it *won't* get thrown out and we'll 404 even before the primaries get error-limited.

I think that's all more about https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672186/ anyway, though -- *this* change is more about making sure that a bunch of unmounted disks in the handoff set don't overwhelm the primary responses (which should be more or less authoritative).

If we wanted to address my earlier comments, we could do something like https://gist.github.com/tipabu/c28fb327c0bf0c74ac418b08e0986395 -- or not, w/e

Thanks for adding the bug to the commit message!'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-03 00:45:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-03 00:52:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

We may still want to revisit https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672186/ in the face of unmounted primaries, but *this* part seems pretty reasonable and separable from that.'}]

commit_message:
Use less responses from handoffs

Since we don't use 404s from handoffs anymore, we need to not let errors
on handoffs overwhelm primary responses either

Change-Id: I2624e113c9d945542f787e5f18f487bd7be3d32e
Closes-Bug: #1857909

messages: [{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-01-02 23:37:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-01-02 23:52:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5805, 'date': '2020-01-03 00:32:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nthis is needed to get things moving so approving with only one review.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-02 23:37:48.000000000', 'message': "Disable bifrost jobs so CI can be fixed

tl;dr: When ironic dropped py2 support, bifrost's
CI reached a point where it could not be fixed without
a massive changeset being created with all required
actions to purge all traces of python2.

In order to work through this, and hopefully make things
better, this change disables the bulk of the CI jobs, marks
the existing primary jobs we want to succeed to be non-voting,
and creates a bionic job as we should ideally already be on
bionic.

The overall plan being to iterate through the jobs and get them
working one at a time as opposed to try and make them all
functional in one changeset.

Change-Id: I9a1e29d1c8bcc4f3cf00df81405f82c22fd10188
"}, {'created': '2020-01-02 23:52:25.000000000', 'message': "Disable bifrost jobs so CI can be fixed

tl;dr: When ironic dropped py2 support, bifrost's
CI reached a point where it could not be fixed without
a massive changeset being created with all required
actions to purge all traces of python2.

In order to work through this, and hopefully make things
better, this change disables the bulk of the CI jobs, marks
the existing primary jobs we want to succeed to be non-voting,
and creates a bionic job as we should ideally already be on
bionic.

The overall plan being to iterate through the jobs and get them
working one at a time as opposed to try and make them all
functional in one changeset.

Change-Id: I9a1e29d1c8bcc4f3cf00df81405f82c22fd10188
"}]
commit_message:
Disable bifrost jobs so CI can be fixed

tl;dr: When ironic dropped py2 support, bifrost's
CI reached a point where it could not be fixed without
a massive changeset being created with all required
actions to purge all traces of python2.

In order to work through this, and hopefully make things
better, this change disables the bulk of the CI jobs, marks
the existing primary jobs we want to succeed to be non-voting,
and creates a bionic job as we should ideally already be on
bionic.

The overall plan being to iterate through the jobs and get them
working one at a time as opposed to try and make them all
functional in one changeset.

Change-Id: I9a1e29d1c8bcc4f3cf00df81405f82c22fd10188

commit_message:
Retool UEFI nvram update

Retool nvram update so we don't absolutely need a UUID, and instead
trust what is located on the disk.

Change-Id: I5856d1972619aea625a71119536075ec1629d9cb

subject: Allow internal clients to use reserved namespace
messages:
[{'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-09-13 19:01:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-09-13 19:03:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Do we want to be able to do this?  What do we think of the X-Backend header interface?

https://gist.github.com/clayg/474bff312804fee7705e106f6327ace7'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-09-19 17:53:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-09-19 18:06:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

(2 comments)

so now all I can create both objects & containers with a null-byte in the path.  Clients are still restricted from doing so because gatekeeper strips out any x-backend headers.

https://gist.github.com/clayg/474bff312804fee7705e106f6327ace7

I think this change should add some additional testing to codify expected behavior before it can merge stand-alone.

but before that I'd also like some feedback on the interface.  Mainly:

1) Should all requests to backend servers be required to forward the X-Backend-Allow-Null-Byte header or is it ok they trust the proxy to do the name check?

I think having dumb backend servers is fine - even in rolling upgrade the proxy will always be doing the null-byte check [1].

2) Should we inspect the method when deciding to do the null-byte check and only revoke client requests that want to *create* resources with a null-byte (i.e. allow client GET/DELETE to null-byte paths?)

But I worry about dropping the client path check on DELETE/POST verbs in at least the versioned writes context since e.g. we'd like clients to only DELETE versions with version API - but I can see the other argument as well.

1. fun side note, when I was testing the change to the account server I realized that my previous change allowed container server's to accept containers with null-bytes - but the account server would still reject the update!  Luckily the container servers would write the async pending and as soon as I fixed the account servers and ran the container-updater everyone was happy.  With this change the in-line PUT /a/c from the container-server to the account layer will let them into the listing right away; but still it's nice to see the swift design helping us out during rolling upgrade."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-09-25 20:14:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

'}, {'created': '2019-11-18 15:25:14.000000000', 'message': "Allow internal clients to use reserved namespace

Reserve the namespace starting with the NULL byte for internal
use-cases.  Backend services will allow path names to include the NULL
byte in urls and validate names in the reserved namespace.  Database
services will filter all names starting with the NULL byte from
responses unless the request includes the header:

    X-Backend-Allow-Reserved-Names: true

The proxy server will not allow path names to include the NULL byte in
urls unless a middlware has set the X-Backend-Allow-Reserved-Names
header.  Middlewares can use the reserved namespace to create objects
and containers that can not be directly manipulated by clients.  Any
objects and bytes created in the reserved namespace will be aggregated
to the user's account totals.

When deploying internal proxys developers and operators may configure
the gatekeeper middleware to translate the X-Allow-Reserved-Names header
to the Backend header so they can manipulate the reserved namespace
directly through the normal API.

Change-Id: If912f71d8b0d03369680374e8233da85d8d38f85

commit_message:
Allow internal clients to use reserved namespace

Reserve the namespace starting with the NULL byte for internal
use-cases.  Backend services will allow path names to include the NULL
byte in urls and validate names in the reserved namespace.  Database
services will filter all names starting with the NULL byte from
responses unless the request includes the header:

    X-Backend-Allow-Reserved-Names: true

The proxy server will not allow path names to include the NULL byte in
urls unless a middlware has set the X-Backend-Allow-Reserved-Names
header.  Middlewares can use the reserved namespace to create objects
and containers that can not be directly manipulated by clients.  Any
objects and bytes created in the reserved namespace will be aggregated
to the user's account totals.

When deploying internal proxys developers and operators may configure
the gatekeeper middleware to translate the X-Allow-Reserved-Names header
to the Backend header so they can manipulate the reserved namespace
directly through the normal API.

UpgradeImpact: it's not safe to rollback from this change

Change-Id: If912f71d8b0d03369680374e8233da85d8d38f85

commit_message:
Simplify octavia post deploy configs

Octavia shares config across multiple services in sometimes unexpected
ways. To avoid problems, this patch merges external deploy tasks
configuration into a single file.

Note: this is a semantic backport of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/687311/

Related-Bug: #1836074

Co-Authored-By: Brent Eagles <beagles@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I081330c28c967aa000ec89f255876d5386599a78

commit_message:
Simplify octavia post deploy configs

Consolidate post deploy configurations in a single file. Octavia
controller services share many configurations. It is best to consolidate
them in the same configuration file. This fixes problems seen like
amphorae not having the controller_ip_port_list config value set on
failover triggered by the Health Manager service as that config was only
being loaded for the Worker service.

Backport note: this backport also includes https://review.opendev.org/696729/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/689875/
Closes-Bug: #1836074

Change-Id: I32524f85ef6a0ca3e87fa9acc8c9e12776225717
(cherry picked from commit c2bb9c0937852d1d5488bc727983fce3435ca898)
(cherry picked from commit 25d8177d143d7933f243543ed12cf4b956167fd1)

subject: Use async tasks for long running common tasks
messages: [{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-12-30 18:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-01-02 20:22:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-30 18:39:51.000000000', 'message': 'Use async tasks for long running common tasks

Use async with poll: 0 for the long running common tasks including:

- puppet host configuration
- container-puppet generate config
- container starting
- container-puppet bootstrap tasks

Executing the tasks in this manner and then polling for the results
causes all of the tasks to be started in parallel across all the nodes,
regardless of the number of ansible forks configured.

The behavior will be that ansible will start the task on the first count
of nodes that matches the configured forks value. Since poll:0, ansible
will immediately move on to the next batch, etc. Effectively, all the
tasks are started in parallel just as quickly as ansible can start them.

The polling tasks (async_status) will then execute in parallel up to the
configured number of forks. As tasks start to finish, ansible moves on
to checking the status of the next batch (again, up to the configured
number of forks). Since most nodes will configure around the same time,
the polling tasks finish roughly at the same time (except for
differences in roles, such as controllers taking much longer).

This behavior results in a signifcant performance improvement at scale,
or when deploying any number of nodes greater than the configured forks
value. Instead of waiting for the first batch to fully complete, all the
nodes are started in parallel.

For example, if puppet host configuration usually takes 5 minutes per
node, and there are 100 nodes, with 25 forks, previously this would have
taken 20 minutes. With this patch, it would now take closer to 5 minutes
for all 100 nodes, plus some overhead for polling.

This more closely matches the behavior previously used with Heat, when
all the nodes were operating in "pull" mode in parallel.

Change-Id: I0c651d127cd2bb179f7592a0519a5fd5064faeb3
(cherry picked from commit 106ce3267fd1471cee184f697f7cb19c695ab36c)
'}]
commit_message:
Use async tasks for long running common tasks

Use async with poll: 0 for the long running common tasks including:

- puppet host configuration
- container-puppet generate config
- container starting
- container-puppet bootstrap tasks

Executing the tasks in this manner and then polling for the results
causes all of the tasks to be started in parallel across all the nodes,
regardless of the number of ansible forks configured.

The behavior will be that ansible will start the task on the first count
of nodes that matches the configured forks value. Since poll:0, ansible
will immediately move on to the next batch, etc. Effectively, all the
tasks are started in parallel just as quickly as ansible can start them.

The polling tasks (async_status) will then execute in parallel up to the
configured number of forks. As tasks start to finish, ansible moves on
to checking the status of the next batch (again, up to the configured
number of forks). Since most nodes will configure around the same time,
the polling tasks finish roughly at the same time (except for
differences in roles, such as controllers taking much longer).

This behavior results in a signifcant performance improvement at scale,
or when deploying any number of nodes greater than the configured forks
value. Instead of waiting for the first batch to fully complete, all the
nodes are started in parallel.

For example, if puppet host configuration usually takes 5 minutes per
node, and there are 100 nodes, with 25 forks, previously this would have
taken 20 minutes. With this patch, it would now take closer to 5 minutes
for all 100 nodes, plus some overhead for polling.

This more closely matches the behavior previously used with Heat, when
all the nodes were operating in "pull" mode in parallel.

Change-Id: I0c651d127cd2bb179f7592a0519a5fd5064faeb3
(cherry picked from commit 106ce3267fd1471cee184f697f7cb19c695ab36c)

commit_message:
Execute deploy_steps_tasks per step

Instead of including the entire deploy_steps_tasks.yaml tasks file for
each role at each step, use the per-step files and only if they exist.

This cuts down on the amount of time that ansible has to spend skipping
tasks that don't get run at a certain step, which can be significant at
scale.

Change-Id: I06ee04b9b47226433f25e3cff08c461462a907d9
(cherry picked from commit 2a6336a742c05e2e6c5fd30a21cd1989823773a1)

commit_message:
Add log collection entry for new ansible file

Durring the container image prepare process the ansible log file will now
be written to a separate file. This change ensures that we collect the file
should it exist. By default the file will be store in the same path as the
created log handler, however in the event that the log handler is only
stream processing the ansible log file will be writtent to /tmp. To ensure
we're collecting the logs correctly, both the /tmp and expected /var/log,
path's have been added to log file array.

Depends-On: Ib208e53619901421d785ca0883f65954f02e59be
Change-Id: Iacc2a015f25266b29feff68bc7ed81b27f9d6aec
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make sure neutron [placement] config section is set

Even if the hiera keys for the [placement] config section
get created [1], the section is not being created/filles as the
::neutron::server::placement class is not included anywhere.

This includes ::neutron::server::placement to have the section
create in the neutron.conf

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/neutron/neutron-api-container-puppet.yaml#L391-L400

Conflicts:
  manifests/profile/base/neutron/server.pp

Change-Id: Iededba802be4b88e3b232a7b7474f2f981e40a08
(cherry picked from commit efbdd0f21b53f4ed9137f463d6765dcc0ece9e41)

commit_message:
Fix Octavia to use correct Puppet class

Addition of octavia::controller::enable_anti_affinity was reverted in
[1] as code to handle that config option already exists in octavia::nova
class. This patch follows that revert and sets THT to use octavia::nova.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699067/

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699074/
Change-Id: I2204b72e40a86892f7312b9af77754d9c11a6c63
(cherry picked from commit e47e7db8a2ee3e59a7c6b71620ba540078f4f123)

commit_message:
Incorrectly derives NeutronPhysnetNUMANodesMapping

This change is to derive the NeutronPhysnetNUMANodesMapping
parameter as dictionary instead of list.

This change doesn't consider the fact that the DHCP port is used for both DHCP and DNS traffic. DNS traffic is L3 and needs routing just like any other port on the network."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2016-09-09 22:40:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Carl, thank you very much, let me make this clear, after this change, VM is still reachable to all networks' agent DHCP port, then DNS is available."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2016-09-09 22:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2016-09-09 23:32:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7448, 'date': '2016-09-10 00:19:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I should be a little more specific to be clearer. In Neutron, the way we have DNS setup -- unless you provide dns servers on the subnet -- is that dnsmasq will forward requests for DNS names that it doesn't serve locally (practically everything on the internet) to upstream DNS servers. The only path it has to forward these requests is through the router to DNS servers on the external network. If the DHCP is not DVR serviceable, how will traffic get to the external network? Unless I forgot something, it has to get forwarded to the SNAT namespace to be NATed."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-09-10 01:03:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

(1 comment)

I added a note to the bug, since you cited the dnsmasq_local_resolv option, which I don't think is a good comparison - that option is just telling dnsmasq it shouldn't look at /etc/resolv.conf, not that it shouldn't provide DNS service.

Will the option you propose basically allow DHCP service but (possibly) no DNS from dnsmasq?"}, {'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2019-05-29 18:04:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-30 01:49:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

 > 
 > I added a note to the bug, since you cited the dnsmasq_local_resolv
 > option, which I don't think is a good comparison - that option is
 > just telling dnsmasq it shouldn't look at /etc/resolv.conf, not
 > that it shouldn't provide DNS service.
 > 
 > Will the option you propose basically allow DHCP service but
 > (possibly) no DNS from dnsmasq?

That may be out of this approach. If user does not set the DNS for a subnet, it will direct to the DHCP port by default. So for my understanding, we should add a default DNS nameserver for all network by default?
