revisions:
[{'created': '2016-09-02 09:35:26.000000000', 'message': "DVR: Ignore DHCP port during DVR host query

Scenario 1, one neutron network has two subnets, and connected all
these subnets to one DVR router.
In the qdhcp-ns the tap-device has all subnets' IP address, and its
directly connected in both subnets. So qrouter-namspace is not needed.

Scenario 2, two neutron networks each have a separate subnet, and
also connect these subnets to one DVR router.
Because this scenario has two different networks, then the DHCP will be
naturally isolated. No need to let all subnets get reachable in such
scenario, aka East/West routing is no needed for DHCP. Let the DHCP
request only process in its own isolated broadcast domain.

Scenario 3, What will happen if a host only run DHCP agent?
qrouter-dvr-namspace will never get hosted, but everything goes fine.

This patch removed the DHCP port device_owner qeury filter during DVR
host query.

Change-Id: I53e20be9b306bf9d3b34ec6a31e3afabd5a0fd6f
Closes-Bug: #1609217
"}, {'created': '2016-09-09 23:32:49.000000000', 'message': "DVR: Ignore DHCP port during DVR host query

Scenario 1, one neutron network has two subnets, and connected all
these subnets to one DVR router.
In the qdhcp-ns the tap-device has all subnets' IP address, and its
directly connected in both subnets. So qrouter-namspace is not needed.

Scenario 2, two neutron networks each have a separate subnet, and
also connect these subnets to one DVR router.
Because this scenario has two different networks, then the DHCP will be
naturally isolated. No need to let all subnets get reachable in such
scenario in a DHCP namespace, aka East/West routing is no needed.
Let the DHCP request only process in its own isolated broadcast domain.

Scenario 3, What will happen if a host only run DHCP agent?
qrouter-dvr-namspace will never get hosted, but everything goes fine.
VM could get an IP without that redundant router namespace.

Scenario 4, any new design/implementation once related to DHCP should
not let DHCP broadcast traffic can go across the domain. Routed
network/subnet may face such concern.

Scenario 5, in order to make DHCP high available, then cloud admins
may aslo run DHCP agent in all/most compute hosts. Then DVR qrouter
namespace may be hosted to those scheduled DHCP agent hosts. Not
needed either.

This patch removed the DHCP port device_owner qeury filter during DVR
host query. Then it will not implicitly set the DVR router namespace
in its connected networks' DHCP agent hosts anymoe. And traffic from
VMs will still be routed due to the routes in dvr local router
(compute node) namespace.

In the DHCP namespace, if that host is not a scheduled DVR router
snat/compute host, we limited the traffic from/to DHCP port to its
own domain, for instace: a dvr router is connected to net1(subnet1)
and net2(subnet2), the DVR snat router is scheduled to network node1,
net1 and net2 DHCP agents are scheduled to network node2, then in
network node2:
1. ip netns exec qdhcp-net1-namesapce `ping net2 IPs is not reachable`;
2. ip netns exec qdhcp-net2-namesapce `ping net1 IPs is not reachable`;
the traffic across DHCP domains will not be routed anymore.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I53e20be9b306bf9d3b34ec6a31e3afabd5a0fd6f
Closes-Bug: #1609217
"}, {'created': '2019-05-24 15:42:28.000000000', 'message': "DVR: Ignore DHCP port during DVR host query

Scenario 1, one neutron network has two subnets, and connected all
these subnets to one DVR router.
In the qdhcp-ns the tap-device has all subnets' IP address, and its
directly connected in both subnets. So qrouter-namspace is not needed.

Scenario 2, two neutron networks each have a separate subnet, and
also connect these subnets to one DVR router.
Because this scenario has two different networks, then the DHCP will be
naturally isolated. No need to let all subnets get reachable in such
scenario in a DHCP namespace, aka East/West routing is no needed.
Let the DHCP request only process in its own isolated broadcast domain.

Scenario 3, What will happen if a host only run DHCP agent?
qrouter-dvr-namspace will never get hosted, but everything goes fine.
VM could get an IP without that redundant router namespace.

Scenario 4, any new design/implementation once related to DHCP should
not let DHCP broadcast traffic can go across the domain. Routed
network/subnet may face such concern.

Scenario 5, in order to make DHCP high available, then cloud admins
may aslo run DHCP agent in all/most compute hosts. Then DVR qrouter
namespace may be hosted to those scheduled DHCP agent hosts. Not
needed either.

This patch adds a config ``host_dvr_for_dhcp`` for the DHCP port
device_owner filter during DVR host query. Then if we set
``host_dvr_for_dhcp = False``, L3-agent will not host the DVR router
namespace in its connected networks' DHCP agent hosts. And traffic
from VMs will still be routed due to the routes in dvr local router
(compute node) namespace.

In the DHCP namespace, if that host is not a scheduled DVR router
snat/compute host, we limited the traffic from/to DHCP port to its
own domain, for instace: a dvr router is connected to net1(subnet1)
and net2(subnet2), the DVR snat router is scheduled to network node1,
net1 and net2 DHCP agents are scheduled to network node2, then in
network node2:
1. ip netns exec qdhcp-net1-namesapce `ping net2 IPs is not reachable`;
2. ip netns exec qdhcp-net2-namesapce `ping net1 IPs is not reachable`;
the traffic across DHCP domains will not be routed anymore.

Closes-Bug: #1609217
Change-Id: I53e20be9b306bf9d3b34ec6a31e3afabd5a0fd6f

commit_message:
DVR: Ignore DHCP port during DVR host query

For large scale deployment, the dvr router will be installed to
the scheduled DHCP host. This will definitely increase the l3
agent service pressure, especially in large number of concurrent
updates, creation, or agent restart.

This patch adds a config ``host_dvr_for_dhcp`` for the DHCP port
device_owner filter during DVR host query. Then if we set
``host_dvr_for_dhcp = False``, L3-agent will not host the DVR router
namespace in its connected networks' DHCP agent hosts.

Closes-Bug: #1609217
Change-Id: I53e20be9b306bf9d3b34ec6a31e3afabd5a0fd6f

commit_message:
image-uploader: allow an image without Labels to be uploaded

Some images, like grafana don't have Labels set; let's just set an empty
default if an image has no Labels and continue the upload.

Change-Id: I571af51db0d21226bc42dc21925384f0129cd581
Closes-Bug: #1857012
(cherry picked from commit 95b68c6d19119a022f94061ba98accc717ff6657)
(cherry picked from commit 95f837bf1ecd563f4f49df1232015e52db72af77)

commit_message:
Add --verbose option to test_matrix.py

This allows getting the debug logging out of test_matrix.py
from the command line which is useful when you're trying to
debug what is wrong with entries in the feature test matrix.

Change-Id: I49aa3d7b60f4df4f32a0a3dbef9b13a97404dbf4

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-20 20:24:43.000000000', 'message': 'Remove 'cinder' service from feature test matrix

The cinder config is including the "cinder" devstack
service which would mean that anything removed explicitly,
like c-bak, is going to be trumped by the fact that 'cinder'
is in the enabled services list in a job.

This removes 'cinder' the service from cinder the config so
that cinder services have to be explicitly enabled/disabled
in the feature test matrix.

Change-Id: I857fbeba2af4a0f038fd2c2a19bb29c2767227a2
'}]
commit_message:
Remove 'cinder' service from feature test matrix

The cinder config is including the "cinder" devstack
service which would mean that anything removed explicitly,
like c-bak, is going to be trumped by the fact that 'cinder'
is in the enabled services list in a job.

This removes 'cinder' the service from cinder the config so
that cinder services have to be explicitly enabled/disabled
in the feature test matrix.

Change-Id: I857fbeba2af4a0f038fd2c2a19bb29c2767227a2

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-28 17:42:38.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add new default roles in os-services API policies

This part of Nova RBAC improvement includes:

1. Add new defaults roles in os-services API policies.

2. Add releasenotes for os-servie API policies listing all
   modification done in this policy.

Migration Plan for Operator:

- Backward compatibility:
  Old rules are maintained with same defaults so that any deployement
  overridden those policy rules will keep working as it is.

- Deprecation Plan:
  Because these policy updates are huge and almost effecting all the nova
  policies, We are defining the two cycle transition plan which used to be
  one cycle for policy and config option modification.

- Below warning can be seen by operator to migrate the old policies
  to new one:

   /opt/stack/nova/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo_policy/policy.py:665: UserWarning: Policy "os_compute_api:os-services":"rule:admin_api" was deprecated in 19.0.0 in favor of "compute:services:disable":"rule:admin_api". Reason:
    Since Stein release, nova API policies are more granular and introducing
    new default roles with scope_type capabilities. These new changes improve
    the security level, manageability. New policies are more rich in term of
    handling access at system and project level with read, write roles. Nova
    APIs are consuming these new policies improvements and automatically
    migrate the old overridden policies. Old policies are silently going to
    be ignored in nova 21.0.0 (OpenStack U) release.
    . Either ensure your deployment is ready for the new default or copy/paste the deprecated policy into your policy file and maintain it manually.

Partial implement blueprint policy-default-refresh

Change-Id: Ia8537923ebe5ce43f48a6e5efefc0a890e6a087d

This adds new defaults roles in os-services API policies.

- Backward compatibility:
  Old rules are maintained as deprecated rule with same defaults
  so that existing deployement will keep working as it is.

- Below warning can be seen by operator to migrate the old policies
  to new one:

   /opt/stack/nova/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo_policy/policy.py:665: UserWarning: Policy "os_compute_api:os-services":"rule:admin_api" was deprecated in 19.0.0 in favor of "compute:services:disable":"rule:admin_api". Reason:
    Since Stein release, nova API policies are more granular and introducing
    new default roles with scope_type capabilities. These new changes improve
    the security level, manageability. New policies are more rich in term of
    handling access at system and project level with read, write roles. Nova
    APIs are consuming these new policies improvements and automatically
    migrate the old overridden policies. Old policies are silently going to
    be ignored in nova 21.0.0 (OpenStack U) release.
    . Either ensure your deployment is ready for the new default or copy/paste the deprecated policy into your policy file and maintain it manually.

This adds new defaults roles in os-services API policies.

- GET is default with system reader role
- Rest all APIs are system asmin role

- Backward compatibility:
    Old Rules and Defaults will keep working as it is because they
    are added as deprecated rules and marked for removal in future
    release. This means Existing deployement will keep working till
    deprecated rules are there.

- Below warning can be seen by operator to migrate the old policies
  to new one:

   /opt/stack/nova/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo_policy/policy.py:665:
UserWarning: Policy "os_compute_api:os-services":"rule:admin_api" was deprecated
in 20.0.0 in favor of "compute:services:list":"role:reader and system_scope:all".
Reason: Since Train release, nova API policies are introducing new default roles
with scope_type capabilities. These new changes improve the security level
and manageability. New policies are more rich in term of handling access
at system and project level token with read, write roles.
Start using the new policies and enable the scope checks via config option
``nova.conf [oslo_policy] enforce_scope=True`` which is False by default.
Old policies are marked as deprecated and silently going to be ignored
in nova 22.0.0 (OpenStack V) release. Either ensure your deployment is ready
for the new default or copy/paste the deprecated policy into your policy file
and maintain it manually.

Start using the new policies and enable the scope checks via config option
``nova.conf [oslo_policy] enforce_scope=True`` which is False by default.
Old policies are marked as deprecated and silently going to be ignored
in nova 22.0.0 (OpenStack V) release. Either ensure your deployment is ready
for the new default or copy/paste the deprecated policy into your policy file
and maintain it manually.

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh

Change-Id: Ia8537923ebe5ce43f48a6e5efefc0a890e6a087d
'}]
commit_message:
Add new default roles in os-services API policies

This adds new defaults roles in os-services API policies.

- GET is default with system reader role
- Rest all APIs are system admin role

Test cases have been added to cover new defaults as well as
for deprecated rules.

- Backward compatibility:
    Old Rules and Defaults will keep working as it is because they
    are added as deprecated rules and marked for removal in future
    release. This means Existing deployement will keep working till
    deprecated rules are there.

- Below warning can be seen by operator to migrate the old policies
  to new one:

   /opt/stack/nova/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo_policy/policy.py:665:
UserWarning: Policy "os_compute_api:os-services":"rule:admin_api" was deprecated
in 20.0.0 in favor of "compute:services:list":"role:reader and system_scope:all".
Reason: Since Train release, nova API policies are introducing new default roles
with scope_type capabilities. These new changes improve the security level
and manageability. New policies are more rich in term of handling access
at system and project level token with read, write roles.
Start using the new policies and enable the scope checks via config option
``nova.conf [oslo_policy] enforce_scope=True`` which is False by default.
Old policies are marked as deprecated and silently going to be ignored
in nova 22.0.0 (OpenStack V) release. Either ensure your deployment is ready
for the new default or copy/paste the deprecated policy into your policy file
and maintain it manually.

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh

Change-Id: Ia8537923ebe5ce43f48a6e5efefc0a890e6a087d

commit_message:
s3api DELETE request return version-id and marker

Make sure that DELETE requests with version-id return the
version-id and delete-marker headers on the response.

Also added some unit tests for checking 501 NotImplemented
responses when object_versioning is not in swift_info

Change-Id: Iaf86223ef80cc36d05fdf5104eb6d92ae4d39505

commit_message:
Add neutron to upper-constraints

Some projects, notably neutron plugins, are using the neutron service as
a library. There is the neutron-lib package, but apparently they have
not moved everything needed over to there yet.

Change-Id: I8e95dc48b8ba2a7e16f1d34eb5ad0e87a3e96f4f
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Dont package .pickl file

because it is not needed and will cause packages to differ for every build.

See https://reproducible-builds.org/ for why this matters.

Similar to previous commit e1d730c2ad95559cb6a0948cf8e99b4eb6eca2c2

Change-Id: Ic0e81412cf0ba3f029bc2f8be52ffdf1ba210b7b

@Sean: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/661676/ modifies the sheepdog driver to support glance multiple stores -- do we want to merge that before removing the driver (in case a maintainer comes along who wants to restore it), or should we not worry about that?'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-19 22:43:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> @Sean: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/661676/ modifies the sheepdog
 > driver to support glance multiple stores -- do we want to merge
 > that before removing the driver (in case a maintainer comes along
 > who wants to restore it), or should we not worry about that?

We certainly could, but based on http://lists.wpkg.org/pipermail/sheepdog/2019-March/068451.html I'm not sure if it's worth the effort. At this point, it's probably best to just get it out of there and move on. If the project somehow revives and someone comes along wanting to get it readded to OpenStack, we at least have the history that they could pull from to get things updated and ready."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-12-19 23:21:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Remove Sheepdog Driver

The Sheepdog project is no longer active and the driver was marked as
unsupported in the Train release. This completes the deprecation process
and removes the driver.

Change-Id: Ie94ae59a29473ca906c6df58a2681714049b16a1
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

subject: Make fluentd-elasticsearch configuration more robust

Done - the new <buffer> configuration seems to be available from 0.14 onwards, so I've swiched it back to 0.12 style."}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-05-30 14:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Thanks Krzysztof, it gets my vote.'}, {'account_id': 29915, 'date': '2019-05-30 16:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Change looks good, I've tested something similar in the past with success. 

Should these changes also be made to ansible/roles/common/templates/conf/output/00-local.conf.j2? 

Just a thought: with the introduction of the buffer, are we exposing some non-preferential default values that might cause the buffer to be discarded too soon? Default settings seem to indicate that the buffer will be deleted after "131072 seconds (roughly 36 hours)" [1] but I am by no means an expert!

I appreciate that the fluent community has decided ~36 hours is an appropriate default, and that this might be a setting best left to admins to change but thought I'd mention it.

Possibly..
retry_limit, disable_retry_limit
"The limit on the number of retries before buffered data is discarded, and an option to disable that limit (if true, the value of retry_limit is ignored and there is no limit). The default values are 17 and false (not disabled). If the limit is reached, buffered data is discarded and the retry interval is reset to its initial value (retry_wait)." [1]

[1] https://docs.fluentd.org/v/0.12/output'}, {'account_id': 29915, 'date': '2019-05-30 17:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Change looks good, I've tested something similar in the past with
 > success.
 > 
 > Should these changes also be made to ansible/roles/common/templates/conf/output/00-local.conf.j2?
 > 
 > Just a thought: with the introduction of the buffer, are we
 > exposing some non-preferential default values that might cause the
 > buffer to be discarded too soon? Default settings seem to indicate
 > that the buffer will be deleted after "131072 seconds (roughly 36
 > hours)" [1] but I am by no means an expert!
 > 
 > I appreciate that the fluent community has decided ~36 hours is an
 > appropriate default, and that this might be a setting best left to
 > admins to change but thought I'd mention it.
 > 
 > Possibly..
 > retry_limit, disable_retry_limit
 > "The limit on the number of retries before buffered data is
 > discarded, and an option to disable that limit (if true, the value
 > of retry_limit is ignored and there is no limit). The default
 > values are 17 and false (not disabled). If the limit is reached,
 > buffered data is discarded and the retry interval is reset to its
 > initial value (retry_wait)." [1]
 > 
 > [1] https://docs.fluentd.org/v/0.12/output

Also https://docs.fluentd.org/v/0.12/buffer:

"retry_limit
The maximum number of retries for sending a chunk (default: 17)
If retry_limit is exceeded, Fluentd will discard the given chunk.

disable_retry_limit
If set true, it disables retry_limit and make Fluentd retry
indefinitely (default: false)."'}, {'account_id': 16036, 'date': '2019-05-31 05:54:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Should these changes also be made to ansible/roles/common/templates/conf/output/00-local.conf.j2?

Yes indeed, I'll add them in the next patchset.

 > Just a thought: with the introduction of the buffer, are we
 > exposing some non-preferential default values that might cause the
 > buffer to be discarded too soon? Default settings seem to indicate
 > that the buffer will be deleted after "131072 seconds (roughly 36
 > hours)" [1] but I am by no means an expert!
 > 
 > I appreciate that the fluent community has decided ~36 hours is an
 > appropriate default, and that this might be a setting best left to
 > admins to change but thought I'd mention it.
 > 
 > Possibly..
 > retry_limit, disable_retry_limit
[...]

I'm not sure - on one hand, I see value in exposing that to the deployers, on the other hand I'm not sure if we're really making any change to the current behaviour (other than preserving the buffer on disk, instead of ram)? In my setup, fluentd is giving up after 19 tries [1]:

```
2019-05-18 19:10:30 +0000 [warn]: #0 failed to flush the buffer. retry_time=19 next_retry_seconds=2019-05-18 21:38:05 +0000 chunk="588f3f6096c3e3b97eed6c013c40e47c" error_class=Fluent::Plugin::ElasticsearchOutput::RecoverableRequestFailure error="could not push logs to Elasticsearch cluster ({:host=>\"monitor.region2\", :port=>9200, :scheme=>\"https\", :user=>\"logstash\", :password=>\"obfuscated\"}): end of file reached (EOFError)"
2019-05-18 21:38:05 +0000 [error]: #0 failed to flush the buffer, and hit limit for retries. dropping all chunks in the buffer queue. retry_times=19 records=306448 error_class=Fluent::Plugin::ElasticsearchOutput::RecoverableRequestFailure error="could not push logs to Elasticsearch cluster ({:host=>\"monitor.region2\", :port=>9200, :scheme=>\"https\", :user=>\"logstash\", :password=>\"obfuscated\"}): end of file reached (EOFError)"
```

I'm not sure I want to change default values from what fluentd developers have picked, but if you think it's beneficial, I can add ansible variables to tweak those if needs be.

[1] Why 19 vs 17 I'm not sure, and that last retry is also a retry so it's 20 retries in total..'}, {'account_id': 29915, 'date': '2019-06-03 15:59:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> 
 > I'm not sure - on one hand, I see value in exposing that to the
 > deployers, on the other hand I'm not sure if we're really making
 > any change to the current behaviour (other than preserving the
 > buffer on disk, instead of ram)? In my setup, fluentd is giving up
 > after 19 tries [1]:
 > 
  > 
 > I'm not sure I want to change default values from what fluentd
 > developers have picked, but if you think it's beneficial, I can add
 > ansible variables to tweak those if needs be.
 > 
 > [1] Why 19 vs 17 I'm not sure, and that last retry is also a retry
 > so it's 20 retries in total..

I've thought on it some more and I agree, I think we should leave this up to fluentd defaults! Sorry for the headache on that one"}, {'account_id': 16036, 'date': '2019-06-04 12:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-06-04 13:17:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 29915, 'date': '2019-06-04 18:26:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-06-19 11:25:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Make fluentd-elasticsearch configuration more robust

Enable reconnect_on_error option so that ES plugin re-establishes
a new session to the ES cluster on errors. Also, enable buffering
to the file, so that the buffer survives container restarts.

Co-Authored-By: Michal Nasiadka <mnasiadka@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Doug Szumski <doug@stackhpc.com>
Closes-Bug: #1830724
Change-Id: Ia40685b9d4fc02194e03c8791ddeb3d29d7f07f6

commit_message:
Add capability for using FQDN in nova compute

This patch set adds in a capability for the user to defaultly use a
FQDN for the nova compute hostname and the hypervisor hostname when
the host is not explicitly specified in the .Values.conf override.

Change-Id: I3243068dfe91ebb97b3885002296a0f454822ec5
Co-authored-by: Drew Walters <andrew.walters@att.com>
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

This is part of the process of removing keystoneclient from

Change-Id: Ie00fc310728c319faf2cfdfb651f0c7a8f48d757

commit_message:
Remove keystoneclient exception usage in tests

This change replaces the usage of keystoneclient exceptions in the
auth_token_middleware unit tests to use the ConnectFailure exception
from keystoneauth.

This is part of the process of removing keystoneclient from
keystonemiddleware.

Change-Id: Ie00fc310728c319faf2cfdfb651f0c7a8f48d757

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-13 13:17:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence issues

Some regex strings contain invalid escape sequences for normal strings,
causing newer version of Python to emit DeprecationWarning messages.
This updates those instances to raw strings so they are not interpreted
as invalid.

Change-Id: I28ac26516bacab36578a5a7f6ec7f9dcf7d7eeb1
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence issues

Some regex strings contain invalid escape sequences for normal strings,
causing newer version of Python to emit DeprecationWarning messages.
This updates those instances to raw strings so they are not interpreted
as invalid.

Change-Id: I28ac26516bacab36578a5a7f6ec7f9dcf7d7eeb1
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-19 15:31:26.000000000', 'message': "Allow network name format to be configured

Currently, when supported, NGS assigns the network UUID as the name of
VLANs in device configuration. Some devices, including Dell Force 10,
do not support VLAN names starting with a number. On Dell Force 10
devices this can result in the following message in neutron DEBUG logs:

Force10-switch(conf-if-vl-3293)#name 555b9c5daccb4e87997fb2b5524cf95e
    % Error: Vlan name should begin with an alphabetic character.

This change allows the format of the network name to be configured via
the 'ngs_network_name_format' configuration option.

Change-Id: Ia8a473c9e0282c5c83f595db6d37b41b52714b55
Story: 1737017
Task: 11728
"}, {'created': '2019-09-20 09:59:23.000000000', 'message': "Allow network name format to be configured

Currently, when supported, NGS assigns the network UUID as the name of
VLANs in device configuration. Some devices, including Dell Force 10,
do not support VLAN names starting with a number. On Dell Force 10
devices this can result in the following message in neutron DEBUG logs:

Force10-switch(conf-if-vl-3293)#name 555b9c5daccb4e87997fb2b5524cf95e
    % Error: Vlan name should begin with an alphabetic character.

This change allows the format of the network name to be configured via
the 'ngs_network_name_format' configuration option.

commit_message:
Allow network name format to be configured

Currently, when supported, NGS assigns the network UUID as the name of
VLANs in device configuration. Some devices, including Dell Force 10,
do not support VLAN names starting with a number. On Dell Force 10
devices this can result in the following message in neutron DEBUG logs:

Force10-switch(conf-if-vl-3293)#name 555b9c5daccb4e87997fb2b5524cf95e
    % Error: Vlan name should begin with an alphabetic character.

This change allows the format of the network name to be configured via
the 'ngs_network_name_format' configuration option.

Change-Id: Ia8a473c9e0282c5c83f595db6d37b41b52714b55
Story: 1737017
Task: 36731

commit_message:
Make nova_novncproxy use BUMPs

We have a lock of VNC version inside repo_packages [1]. We should
try using it as otherwise this may result in broken console

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/src/branch/stable/stein/playbooks/defaults/repo_packages/nova_consoles.yml#L33

Change-Id: Icd1fe43c9fa3ab16f9bdaf0a2cb60854c0e15e97

commit_message:
Add host validation after live migration

test_server_connectivity_live_migration was passing even in case
live migration was aborted e.g. like in case documented in [1].
This patch adds validation that server actually migrated.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1852064

Change-Id: If6493ec4c849618fdd52a7e725f44537ab33d16a

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-14 02:07:23.000000000', 'message': 'Ingress: k8s API transition support

Updates the ClusterRole used by the ingress service account to grant
access to Ingress resources via either the extensions/v1beta1 or
networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API. Does not change the apiVersion used
when creating Ingress resources.

Reference:
https://kubernetes.io/blog/2019/07/18/api-deprecations-in-1-16/

The v1.20 release will stop serving the following deprecated
API versions in favor of newer and more stable API versions:
Ingress (in the extensions/v1beta1 API group)

Migrate to use the networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API, serving Ingress since
v1.14. Existing persisted data can be retrieved/updated via the
networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API.

Change-Id: I67d4dbdb3834ca4ac8ce90ec51c8d6414ce80a01
'}, {'created': '2019-12-18 03:10:07.000000000', 'message': 'Ingress: k8s and ingress version compatibility

k8s 1.14 enabled Ingress on the networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API, while
still serving it via extensions/v1beta1. [0]

ingress-nginx 0.25.0 actually uses the networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API,
which requires updated RBAC rules. [1]

This change updates the ClusterRole used by the ingress service account
to grant access to Ingress resources via either the extensions/v1beta1
or networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API, aligning with the static manifests
from the kubernetes/ingress-nginx repo [2]. It does not change the
apiVersion used when creating Ingress resources.

[0] https://kubernetes.io/blog/2019/07/18/api-deprecations-in-1-16/
[1] https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/releases/tag/nginx-0.25.0
[2] https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/870be3bcd88c267f14fd82da82303472f383cd14/deploy/static/mandatory.yaml#L50-L106

Change-Id: I67d4dbdb3834ca4ac8ce90ec51c8d6414ce80a01

commit_message:
Ingress: k8s and ingress version compatibility

k8s 1.14 first enabled Ingress in the networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API
group, while still serving it in the extensions/v1beta1 API group. The
extensions/v1beta1 API endpoint is deprecated in 1.16 and scheduled for
removal in 1.20. [0]

ingress-nginx 0.25.0 actually uses the networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API,
which requires updated RBAC rules. [1]

This change updates the ClusterRole used by the ingress service account
to grant access to Ingress resources via either the extensions/v1beta1
or networking.k8s.io/v1beta1 API, aligning with the static manifests
from the kubernetes/ingress-nginx repo [2]. It does not change the
apiVersion used when creating Ingress resources.

[0] https://kubernetes.io/blog/2019/07/18/api-deprecations-in-1-16/
[1] https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/releases/tag/nginx-0.25.0
[2] https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/870be3bcd88c267f14fd82da82303472f383cd14/deploy/static/mandatory.yaml#L50-L106

commit_message:
redfish-vmedia: correctly pass ipa-debug

The PXE/iPXE boot interfaces pass ipa-debug=1 when debugging is
enabled in ironic. The vmedia boot interface should do the same.

Change-Id: Ifd97eeebc95845a32c2d3ece513c25fdb52812d3

'}, {'created': '2019-12-16 14:31:28.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] Test CentOS8

Change-Id: I98fc088cd87c1412544f9590ce7a925b413297e2
(cherry picked from commit c7f2a048be27c230b6def6af8b01d51cb6738622)
'}, {'created': '2019-12-19 07:30:15.000000000', 'message': "Add CentOS8 support and jobs

- scenario001 and 004 will be running without ceph
  until ceph repos get available for CentOS8
- scenario003 will run not run with linuxbridge until next CentOS
  minor version as it has issues:-
    - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1720637
- Add Puppetfile_centos8 to have different puppet modules
  as compared to other distros. Currently only puppet-mysql
  needs to be different, but it's done keeping in mind in future
  we may need to use different versions for other modules.
- check for rdo_dlrn url existence only for RedHat distros.

Change-Id: I98fc088cd87c1412544f9590ce7a925b413297e2
(cherry picked from commit 5387d04e28f60403e36fa723c9bb2679932b39ef)
"}, {'created': '2019-12-19 08:55:03.000000000', 'message': "Add CentOS8 support and jobs

- scenario001 and 004 will be running without ceph
  until ceph repos get available for CentOS8
- scenario003 will run not run with linuxbridge until next CentOS
  minor version as it has issues:-
    - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1720637
- Add Puppetfile_centos8 to have different puppet modules
  as compared to other distros. Currently only puppet-mysql
  needs to be different, but it's done keeping in mind in future
  we may need to use different versions for other modules.
- check for rdo_dlrn url existence only for RedHat distros.

commit_message:
Add CentOS8 support and jobs

- scenario001 and 004 will be running without ceph
  until ceph repos get available for CentOS8
- scenario003 will run not run with linuxbridge until next CentOS
  minor version as it has issues:-
    - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1720637
- Add Puppetfile_centos8 to have different puppet modules
  as compared to other distros. Currently only puppet-mysql and
  puppet-rabbitmq needs to be different due to older versions of
  mariadb and rabbitmq-server, but it's done keeping in mind in future
  we may need to use different versions for other modules.
- check for rdo_dlrn url existence only for RedHat distros.

Change-Id: I98fc088cd87c1412544f9590ce7a925b413297e2
(cherry picked from commit 5387d04e28f60403e36fa723c9bb2679932b39ef)

commit_message:
Update proxy documentation for AIO

This change adds in information about overriding the dns entries
that can end up overwriting the existing ones in resolv.conf
and resulting in a lack of network connectivity when deploying
AIO behind a proxy.

Change-Id: I9faab36a114e28fe8f4c312e7cd64a582333033b

commit_message:
WIP - Change /etc/keystone dir permissions to 400

This change introduces an init-container to change the permissions
of the keystone config directory to 400 to remove the world-readable
flag from any existing files.

subject: Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env
messages: [{'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-12-23 10:26:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-26 11:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-01-02 13:05:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-23 10:26:40.000000000', 'message': 'Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: I8265a57695739585760047c15eedae833c7c3653
'}]
commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: I8265a57695739585760047c15eedae833c7c3653

commit_message:
OpenID Connect improved support

OpenID Connect is supported in Keystone by leveraging the Apache
mod_auth_oidc module and the Keystone Federation plugin. OpenID Connect
works fine when accessing OpenStack thorugh the dashboard, but it
requires additional configuration steps to make it work when using the
OpenStack CLI tools. This spec aims at improving the support, so
that the same outcome is obtained, regardless of the way the user
accesses the cloud.

Implements blueprint: improved-oidc-support

Change-Id: I97f7a34d398ba673d7733fb2aaa490ebc9298afd

commit_message:
Add SyslogIdenfier to healthcheck systemd unit

Adding this new field will allow to filter all healthcheck logs using
the Idenfier value.

For instance, using journalctl, you would be able to run this:
`journalctl -t healthcheck_collectd'

It will also allow to get a dedicated file out of (r)syslog if needed.

Change-Id: Icdc5caf4cedc46291a807c39c0a31c74955a4a74
Closes-Bug: #1856573

commit_message:
Fix Octavia to use correct Puppet class

Addition of octavia::controller::enable_anti_affinity was reverted in
[1] as code to handle that config option already exists in octavia::nova
class. This patch follows that revert and sets THT to use octavia::nova.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699067/

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699074/
Change-Id: I2204b72e40a86892f7312b9af77754d9c11a6c63

commit_message:
Remove tempest fsoverrides in favor of featureset vars

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698211/ moves the ostempest
vars to featureset. So we are removing the same from here and
reuse it from fs itself.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698211/

Change-Id: I45a608150f054c5e5ae0a5109ab57d3d9963f434
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Replace CentOS 7 images with CentOS 8

CentOS 7 uses Python 2. Although it's possible to install Python 3
on it, it not trivial with DIB. We should rather switch to
a distribution where Python 3 is the default version.

As a nice side effect, the CentOS 8 images seem smaller.

The CentOS 7 job definitions are kept around since they're used
on stable/train.

Change-Id: I6b23da21eab19c69f7b070adff76b35e1752bf8d

nodes in manageable state for introspection workflow. Since there

YAQL is suboptimal.
Moreover this does not work in large environments because default

state might not detect in introspection.

commit_message:
Using API instead yaql to get manageable nodes

Currently tripleo.baremetal.v1 workbook is using YAQL to filter
nodes in manageable state for introspection workflow. Since there
is a way to get manageable nodes using client parameter [1] using
YAQL is suboptimal.
Moreover this does not work in large environments because default
`limit` argument [2] does not list all nodes and nodes in manageable
state might not detect in introspection.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/python-ironicclient/blob/master/ironicclient/v1/node.py#L75-L76
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/python-ironicclient/blob/master/ironicclient/v1/node.py#L80-L87

Change-Id: Id11adaa426487ed4f3ce4148c84f750cba1c0c11
Closes-Bug: #1856031

commit_message:
Add no-constraints job for py37

Some repos, such as reviewstats, use no-constraints jobs since they are
not bound by the same constraints as official OpenStack projects.

This adds a variant using py37 to allow moving beyond the current max
version of py35.

Change-Id: Ibc3aba9e5adffe7a3efab1f4b5bfe7ff48a179b8
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: Ifcf0cab0b3f6a828a756ca8e5efe6e262c20fe30

commit_message:
Remove python2 from project-template

We're unwinding python2 testing. As part of doing that, remove
python2 from our zuul project-template which other people are
using to add tips jobs to their project.

Change-Id: I1bdb248ba677c41e456dcac3dd6f08151de4a9f8

commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: I1fb4f75c36bf8d9b93f3892627095b64c0522bf9

commit_message:
Fix sshd firewall rule

After migration to tripleo-ansible firewall role with [1],
firwall rules for sshd were not applied correctly as value
of heat param SshFirewallAllowAll was not being honored.
This patch fixes it by using conditions properly.

Issue was not hit in CI in CentOS7 jobs as rule to allow
access to port 22 is done while creating nodepool images with
nodepool-base element. Issue got visible in rhel8 jobs(rhel8
nodepool images don't have nodepool-base element applied due
to [3]) after [2] was merged which fixed apply of DROP rules.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/677237/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699692/
[3] https://softwarefactory-project.io/r/#/c/15863/

Closes-Bug: #1857463
Change-Id: Ifd5db368d63e89150c5c46877cd20e1e4a65a08c

commit_message:
Tempest cleanup: improve iterating over projects

Currently cleanup iterates over projects and deletes all resources
tied to a particular project. However, most of the resources can be
deleted all at once without iteration over the projects.
This will fix the mentioned bug and also make the tool much more
efficient as we'll avoid many iterations and queries.

Closes-bug: #1830943
Change-Id: I82c7899a32bee0e714e71d703195085e10ea224f

commit_message:
Fix upper and lower constraints

- Mistral has some newer lower requirements.
- Adds the upper contraints file in the 'deps' tox attribute.
- Removes 'VIRTUAL_ENV' environment variable, which is useless here.

Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ia0c67c5980a7e6bc9006a24be775ea6fb815d23c

That's handled by keystone, when a region is deleted the code looks for child regions [1] and deletes them too [2]. Maybe a small note could be added in the delete method mentioning this so that we won't find ourselves in the future looking for this info again.

Extend cleanup CLI to delete regions

RegionService class enables deletion of regions which were
neglected by tempest cleanup before.

Closes-Bug: #1848672

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-26 17:08:03.000000000', 'message': 'translation: drop babel extractor definitions

babel extractors are now registered via python entry points,
so there is no need to declare babel extractors in babel configs.

This change is important to make translation work in Django 2.2.
django-babel does not work with Django 2.2 and looks unmaintained
for over two years. The horizon team is thinking to switch the extractor
to enmerkar (a fork of django-babel) to make extraction of translation
string work again near future. It is important to drop the extractor
definition to make the transition smooth.

Change-Id: I6af7b37f310a8c76155c9686a78608cde0adccd8
'}]
commit_message:
translation: drop babel extractor definitions

babel extractors are now registered via python entry points,
so there is no need to declare babel extractors in babel configs.

This change is important to make translation work in Django 2.2.
django-babel does not work with Django 2.2 and looks unmaintained
for over two years. The horizon team is thinking to switch the extractor
to enmerkar (a fork of django-babel) to make extraction of translation
string work again near future. It is important to drop the extractor
definition to make the transition smooth.

Change-Id: I6af7b37f310a8c76155c9686a78608cde0adccd8

commit_message:
REmove double docs jobs from jjb

jenkins-job-builder has two docs templates, since
I5cbf7b5cfea349a0bd72d2abee40710175cf5b2f as newest change added
docs-on-readthedocs, remove the older publish-tox-docs-infra, jjb is not
really part of infra anymore and publishing to rtd works fine.

Remove also link to it from our index page.

Change-Id: I803dc997f713896f557ccd22ff358adb28c9bf6b

[{'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-12-05 11:52:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-12-05 11:53:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-12-05 12:03:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-12-05 12:06:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-12-05 12:32:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This change is valid when we're looking for the lvm2 package on the overcloud, but I'm thinking about turning this playbook in a more generic set of tasks that, given a list of ceph dependencies (packages), we can execute it for all of them:

```
---
- name: Gather the package facts
  package_facts:
    manager: auto

- name: Warn about missing dependencies
  warn:
    msg: "If planning to use Ceph, it is necessary to check {{ item }} is installed!"
  when:
    - "'{{ item }}' not in ansible_facts.packages"
  with_items:
    - "{{ packages }}"

- name: Fail if a ceph dependency is missing
  fail:
    msg: "If planning to use Ceph, it is necessary to install the {{item}} package"
  delegate_to: overcloud
  when:
    - "'{{ item }}' not in ansible_facts.packages"
  with_items:
    - "{{ packages }}"
```

This can help for the future if packages will be added.
Of course this is something we're doing on the overcloud, so I think we should keep the ceph-ansible check separated.

@John/@Giulio/@Gael wdyt? commit_message:
Add a validation to fail if a Ceph dependency is not installed

When the overcloud is deployed with Ceph we need to install all the
ceph dependencies on the overcloud nodes.
If a ceph dependency is missing, a warning message is displayed and we
can also let the playbook fail setting the related boolean.
Furthermore, if the package is found, the playbook check if a new
version is available.

Closes-Bug: 1855692
Change-Id: I85d09955e839bab35cc06d2f0906f3012c8a1aa9

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

We currently retry when podman run returns with exit code 0 and 2.
in container-puppet.py. It's possible that container storage bits
are already created for failure. It's better to delete the container

commit_message:
Try deleting container for failures too

We currently retry when podman run returns with exit code 0 and 2.
in container-puppet.py. It's possible that container storage bits
are already created for failure. It's better to delete the container
and it's storage before retrying.

Change-Id: I4449c52b954c27e31553230cbdbd0949ae6413d6
Related-Bug: #1856086

ugh, disregard the previous comment was aiming https://review.opendev.org/688662'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-17 16:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-18 08:58:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 28.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-18 10:09:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 29.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-18 12:12:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 30: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-18 12:13:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-18 14:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 31.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-18 14:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 31:

This works stable for my testing and shows good results in benchmarks

It’s 13% faster,
for a 8-36% it  better deduplicates (creates more hardlinks) layers,
and as a consequence, it’s 25% less often connects container registries via HTTP(s)

In multi-thread mode, it never re-fetches layers once processed it a first time.

For multi-process workers, it reduces the numbers of re-fetched layers, but in order to make it 0, a further work needed to implement multiprocess.Manager().dict() as a shared an SMP-safe global view instead of the current cls.uploaded_layers.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-21 09:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 32.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-21 12:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32: Workflow-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-08 12:55:44.000000000', 'message': 'Track uploaded layers for for workers global view

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into-serve registry
yet.

Lower level changes explained:
* Make workers tracking the global view for the uploaded layers and
  do not allow taking a lock for such layers. That prevents multiple
  fetching of the same layer, which also exists in the image-serve
  files and is ready for post-processing (like cross-linking it).
* Make locks management universal for objects and move it to the base
  image uploader class so we could access the global tracking state
  of the uploaded layers in the _fetch_lock as well.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-10-09 15:11:59.000000000', 'message': 'Track uploaded layers for workers as global view

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into-serve registry
yet.

Make workers tracking the global view for the uploaded layers in the
fast in-memory cache and do not allow taking a lock for such layers.
That prevents multiple fetching of the same layer, which also exists in
the image-serve files and is ready for post-processing (like
cross-linking it). That also speeds up that if-layer-exists check
executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Also make locks management universal for objects (not only layers
specific) - this is needed for follow-up work.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

'}, {'created': '2019-10-10 09:46:23.000000000', 'message': 'Track uploaded layers for workers as global view

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into-serve registry
yet.

Make workers tracking the global view for the uploaded layers in the
fast in-memory cache and do not allow taking a lock for such layers.
That prevents multiple fetching of the same layer, which also exists in
the image-serve files and is ready for post-processing (like
cross-linking it). That also speeds up that if-layer-exists check
executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Additionally fix the exit conditions when ImageUploaderThreadException
needs to be processed by the locks manager or the caller side: reraise
it by the locks manager after the retries limit has been reached so that
the caller process could react on it. It will wait until the locked
layer completed then skipped (ImageUploaderSkippedException), or
unlocked, or other exception arrives.

Also make locks management universal for objects (not only layers
specific) - this is needed for follow-up work.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-10-10 13:16:33.000000000', 'message': 'Track uploaded layers for workers as global view

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into the image-serve
registry yet. Later on, when trying to cross-reference that layer for
another images, leverage the in-memory cache of the global view to
locate that already processed image, had it been apparently stored
into the local registry and got the OS system path.

Make workers tracking the global view for digests of the uploaded
layers in the fast in-memory metadata cache and do not allow taking a
lock for such layers. That prevents multiple fetching of the same
layer, which also exists in the image-serve files and is ready for
post-processing (like cross-linking it). That also speeds up that
if-layer-exists check executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Additionally fix the exit conditions when ImageUploaderThreadException
needs to be processed by the locks manager or the caller side: reraise
it by the locks manager after the retries limit has been reached so that
the caller process could react on it. It will wait until the locked
layer completed then skipped (ImageUploaderSkippedException), or
unlocked, or other exception arrives.

Also make locks management universal for objects (not only layers
specific) - this is needed for follow-up work.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-10-10 13:44:16.000000000', 'message': 'Track uploaded layers for workers as global view

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into the image-serve
registry yet. Later on, when trying to cross-reference that layer for
another images, leverage the in-memory cache of the global view to
locate that already processed image, had it been apparently stored
into the local registry and got the OS system path.

Make workers tracking the global view for digests of the uploaded
layers in the fast in-memory metadata cache and do not allow taking a
lock for such layers. That prevents multiple fetching of the same
layer, which also exists in the image-serve files and is ready for
post-processing (like cross-linking it). That also speeds up that
if-layer-exists check executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Additionally fix the exit conditions when ImageUploaderThreadException
needs to be processed by the locks manager or the caller side: reraise
it by the locks manager after the retries limit has been reached so that
the caller process could react on it. It will wait until the locked
layer completed then skipped (ImageUploaderSkippedException), or
unlocked, or other exception arrives.

Also make locks management universal for objects (not only layers
specific) - this is needed for follow-up work.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-10-11 09:11:22.000000000', 'message': 'Track uploaded layers for workers as global view

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into the image-serve
registry yet. Later on, when trying to cross-reference that layer for
another images, leverage the in-memory cache of the global view to
locate that already processed image, had it been apparently stored
into the local registry and got the OS system path.

That opptimizes the amount of outbound HTTP requests to registries,
when doing multiple fetching of the same cross-referenced layer
that also exists in the image-serve files. That also speeds up the
if-layer-exists check executed against the in-memory cache
firstly.

Additionally fix the waiting & exit conditions in the locks manager
to really keep retrying until we no longer have collisions.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-10-14 15:10:55.000000000', 'message': 'Track uploaded layers for workers as global view

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into the image-serve
registry yet. Later on, when trying to cross-reference that layer for
another images, leverage the in-memory cache of the global view to
locate that already processed image, had it been apparently stored
into the local registry and got the OS system path. The referenced
image name is also stored for the cached metadata of the known layer
and is used as a complementing method of discovering the source image
name from URL, when cross linking it with the target image layers.
This extends the logic built around image_layers.

Ultimately, that opptimizes the amount of outbound HTTP requests to
registries, when doing multiple fetching of the same cross-referenced
layer that also exists in the image-serve files. That also speeds up
the if-layer-exists check executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Additionally fix the waiting & exit conditions in the locks manager
to really keep retrying until we no longer have collisions.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-10-18 12:12:25.000000000', 'message': "Track layers for upload workers to not repeat itself

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into the image-serve
registry yet. Later on, when trying to cross-reference that layer for
another images, leverage the in-memory cache of the global view to
locate that already processed image, had it been apparently stored
into the local registry and got the OS system path. The referenced
image name is also stored for the cached metadata of the known layer
and is used as a complementing method of discovering the source image
name from URL, when cross linking it with the target image layers.
This extends the logic built around image_layers.

Ultimately, that opptimizes the amount of outbound HTTP requests to
registries, when doing multiple fetching of the same cross-referenced
layer that also exists in the image-serve files. That also speeds up
the if-layer-exists check executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Addititional changes that should be in a single unit of work
(otherwise it only makes things running much longer, if applied as
separate changes):

* Add missing lock handler when locking a layer

The original change I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007
introduced locking of layers. Later the dynamic split
I60507eba9884a0660fe269da5ad27b0e57a70ca8 came for the multi-process vs
multi-threading execution pools and introduced the lock variable that
must be passed through all of the locking-mode (MP/MT) dependent
places to never confuse it with the ongoing SMP work types.

If we loose that locking mode information, like when fetching
a layer lock, things might (and surely will) go awry. Let's fix that
and always issue locks and unlocks passing the locking method
information into it.

* Always lock layers being checked for its existance

When copying a local layer to registry we do not issue a lock
for the layer existance check. But we do, when copying a layer
from registry to registry. This doesn't look like a consistent
behavior, therefore issue a lock for both cases.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-10-18 14:06:23.000000000', 'message': "Track layers for upload workers to not repeat itself

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into the image-serve
registry yet. Later on, when trying to cross-reference that layer for
another images, leverage the in-memory cache of the global view to

This extends the logic built around image_layers.

Ultimately, that opptimizes the amount of outbound HTTP requests to

* Always lock layers being checked for its existance

When copying a local layer to registry we do not issue a lock

Partial-bug: #1847225

"}, {'created': '2019-10-22 10:24:17.000000000', 'message': "Track layers for upload workers to not repeat itself

Make image upload workers processing only the 1st time seen layers,
which is ones that have never been uploaded into the image-serve
registry yet. Later on, when trying to cross-reference that layer for
another images, leverage the in-memory cache of the global view to
locate that already processed image, had it been apparently stored
into the local registry and got the OS system path. The referenced
image name is also stored for the cached metadata of the known layer
and is used as a complementing method of discovering the source image
name from URL, when cross linking it with the target image layers.
This extends the logic built around image_layers.

Extend the dynamic executor type selector for more cases, like when
copying layers from a registry to a registry. Given the added
shared global view, we are no longer limited here to use only
multi-threading workers, nor should we longer execute the 1st task
in the tasks list as a separate (and non-concurrent) job.

Automatically pick the best possible multi-workers mode as the
following:

* if it cannot use multi-process workers, like when executing it via
  Mistral by monkey patched eventlet greenthreads, choose threadinglock
  and multi-threads safe standard dictionary in the shared class
  namespace to store the global view into uploaded layers of images
* if it can do MP, pick processlock and the safe (from data races)
  Manager().dict() as the global view shared among cooperating OS
  processes.
* use that global view in a transparent fashion, provided by a special
  classmethod proxying access to the internal state shared for workers.
* also apply the dynamic selection if using tripleo CLI

Ultimately, all that allows never re-fetching the already processed
layers, opptimizes the amount of outbound HTTP requests to registries
issued for the same cross-referenced layer that exists in the local
image-serve registry files. That also speeds up the if-layer-exists
check executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Addititional changes that should be in a single unit of work
(otherwise it only makes things running much longer, if applied as
separate changes):

* Add missing lock handler when locking a layer

The original change I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007
introduced locking of layers. Later the dynamic split
I60507eba9884a0660fe269da5ad27b0e57a70ca8 came for the multi-process vs
multi-threading execution pools and introduced the lock variable that
must be passed through all of the locking-mode (MP/MT) dependent
places to never confuse it with the ongoing SMP work types.

If we loose that locking mode information, like when fetching
a layer lock, things might (and surely will) go awry. Let's fix that
and always issue locks and unlocks passing the locking method
information into it.

* Always lock layers being checked for its existance

When copying a local layer to registry we do not issue a lock
for the layer existance check. But we do, when copying a layer
from registry to registry. This doesn't look like a consistent
behavior, therefore issue a lock for both cases.

Partial-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

"}, {'created': '2019-10-22 12:21:48.000000000', 'message': "Make upload workers never re-process image layers

Make image upload workers processing each layer exactly once and
avoid re-fetching it from a registry.

When cross-linking that known layer for another images, leverage the
in-memory cache (the global view among all workers) to locate that
already processed image, had it been apparently stored into the local
registry and got the OS system path.

The cross-referenced image name is also stored for the cached metadata
of that known layer and is used as a complementing method of
discovering the source image name from URL, when cross linking it with
the target image layers. This extends the logic built around
image_layers.

Having that global view implemented we may no longer upload the 1st
image in the tasks list as a separate (and non-concurrent) job. Neither
have we to keep randomizing the images/layers scheduled for uploading
(leaving reverting of the latter for follow-ups).

Based on the dynamically picked multi-workers mode provide the global
view state synchronization as the following:

* if it cannot use multi-process workers, like when executing it via
  Mistral by monkey patched eventlet greenthreads, choose threadinglock
  and multi-threads-safe standard dictionary in the shared class
  namespace to store the global view there
* if it can do MP, pick processlock and its (safe from data races)
  Manager().dict() as the global view shared among cooperating OS
  processes.
* use that global view in a transparent fashion, provided by a special
  classmethod proxying access to the internal state shared for workers.

Ultimately, all that allows never re-fetching the already processed
layers, opptimizes the amount of outbound HTTP requests to registries
issued for the same cross-referenced layer that exists in the local
image-serve registry files. That also speeds up the if-layer-exists
check executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Addititional changes that should be in a single unit of work
(otherwise it only makes things running much longer, if applied as
separate changes):

* Add missing lock handler when locking a layer

The original change I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007
introduced locking of layers. Later the dynamic split
I60507eba9884a0660fe269da5ad27b0e57a70ca8 came for the multi-process vs
multi-threading execution pools and introduced the lock variable that
must be passed through all of the locking-mode (MP/MT) dependent
places to never confuse it with the ongoing SMP work types.

If we loose that locking mode information, like when fetching
a layer lock, things might (and surely will) go awry. Let's fix that
and always issue locks and unlocks passing the locking method
information into it.

* Always lock layers being checked for its existance

When copying a local layer to registry we do not issue a lock
for the layer existance check. But we do, when copying a layer
from registry to registry. This doesn't look like a consistent
behavior, therefore issue a lock for both cases.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

image-serve registry files. That also speeds up the if-layer-exists
check executed against the in-memory cache firstly.

Addititional changes that should be in a single unit of work
(otherwise it only makes things running much longer, if applied as
separate changes):

* Add missing lock handler when locking a layer

The original change I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007
introduced locking of layers. Later the dynamic split
I60507eba9884a0660fe269da5ad27b0e57a70ca8 came for the multi-process vs
multi-threading execution pools and introduced the lock variable that
must be passed through all of the locking-mode (MP/MT) dependent
places to never confuse it with the ongoing SMP work types.

If we loose that locking mode information, like when fetching
a layer lock, things might (and surely will) go awry. Let's fix that
and always issue locks and unlocks passing the locking method
information into it.

* Always lock layers being checked for its existance

When copying a local layer to registry we do not issue a lock
for the layer existance check. But we do, when copying a layer
from registry to registry. This doesn't look like a consistent
behavior, therefore issue a lock for both cases.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-10-25 17:14:55.000000000', 'message': "Make upload workers faster on processing layers

Make upload workers processing image layers only once (as the best
effort) and avoid re-fetching it from a registry.

Whether cross-linking that known layer for another local images, or
performing cross-repo blobs patching, leverage the cached in memory
global view shared for all workers to speed-up processing of that
already processed layer.

The 1st time a layer gets uploaded for an image, that image and
known path (local or remote) becomes a reference for future
cross-references, which are also tracked in the global view graph.

Use graf traversal to complete layers cross-linking or cross-repo
blobs mounting (depending on the local/remote kind of the
referencing image).

Having that global view implemented skip uploading the 1st image in
the tasks list as a separate (and non-concurrent) job.

Global view (graph) under-the-hood:

graf:
  local: #scope
    layer1:
     ref: <im1> # the reference image details for the layer1
     path: <>
     targets: # other images referencing that layer1, by any scope
       - im2: <kind> # either local or remote scope
       - im6: <kind>
  remote: #scope
    layer42:
      ref: <im2>
      path: <>
      targets:
        - im1: <>
        - im42: <>
    layer1: # yes, it may be tracked for both scopes as well
      ...

Based on the dynamically picked multi-workers mode, provide the global
view graf state synchronization as the following:

* if it cannot use multi-process workers, like when executing it via
  Mistral by monkey patched eventlet greenthreads, choose threadinglock
  and multi-threads-safe standard dictionary in the shared class
  namespace to store the global view there
* if it can do MP, pick processlock and its (safe from data races)
  Manager().dict() as the global view shared among cooperating OS
  processes.
* use that global view in a transparent fashion, provided by a special
  classmethod proxying access to the internal state shared for workers.

Ultimately, all that optimizes:

* completion time
* re-fetching of the already processed layers
* local deduplication of layers
* the amount of outbound HTTP requests to registries
* if-layer-exists and other internal logic check executed against the
  in-memory cache firstly.

Additionally, always lock layers being checked for its existance.
When copying a local layer to a registry we do not issue a lock
for the layer existance check. But we do, when copying a layer
from registry to registry. This doesn't look like a consistent
behavior, therefore issue a lock for both cases.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-10-31 11:21:48.000000000', 'message': 'Make upload workers faster on processing layers

Make upload workers processing image layers only once (as the best
effort). When fetching source layer, cross-link it for the target
local image, whenever that source is already exists. When pushing a
layer to a target registry, do not repeat transfering the same data,
if already pushed earlier for another image.

The 1st time a layer gets uploaded/fetched for an image, that image and
its known path (local or remote) becomes a reference for future
cross-referencing by other images.

Store information about already processed layers in global view shared
for all workers to speed-up data transfering jobs they execute.

Having that global view, uploading the 1st image in the tasks list as a
separate (and non-concurrent) job becomes redundant and now will be
executed concurently with other images.

Based on the dynamically picked multi-workers mode, provide the global
view as a graf with its MP/MT state synchronization as the following:

* if it cannot use multi-process workers, like when executing it via
  Mistral by monkey patched eventlet greenthreads, choose threadinglock
  and multi-threads-safe standard dictionary in the shared class
  namespace to store the global view there
* if it can do MP, pick processlock and its (safe from data races)
  Manager().dict() as the global view shared among cooperating OS
  processes.
* use that global view in a transparent fashion, provided by a special
  classmethod proxying access to the internal state shared for workers.

Ultimately, all that optimizes:

* completion time
* re-fetching of the already processed layers
* local deduplication of layers
* the amount of outbound HTTP requests to registries
* if-layer-exists and other internal logic check executed against the
  in-memory cache firstly.

As layers locking and unlocking becomes a popular action, reduce the
noise of the debug messages it produces.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

  namespace to store the global view there
* if it can do MP, pick processlock and its (safe from data races)
  Manager().dict() as the global view shared among cooperating OS
  processes.
* use that global view in a transparent fashion, provided by a special
  classmethod proxying access to the internal state shared for workers.

Ultimately, all that optimizes:

* completion time
* re-fetching of the already processed layers
* local deduplication of layers
* the amount of outbound HTTP requests to registries
* if-layer-exists and other internal logic check executed against the
  in-memory cache firstly.

As layers locking and unlocking becomes a popular action, reduce the
noise of the debug messages it produces.

commit_message:
Make upload workers faster on processing layers

Make upload workers processing image layers only once (as the best
effort). This also reworks and simplifies locks management for
individual tasks now managed for the PythonImageUploader class
namespace only.

When fetching source layer, cross-link it for the target
local image, whenever that source is already exists. When pushing a
layer to a target registry, do not repeat transfering the same data,
if already pushed earlier for another image.

The 1st time a layer gets uploaded/fetched for an image, that image and
its known path (local or remote) becomes a reference for future
cross-referencing by other images.

Store such information about already processed layers in global view
shared for all workers to speed-up data transfering jobs they execute.

Having that global view, uploading the 1st image in the tasks list as a
separate (and non-concurrent) job becomes redundant and now will be
executed concurently with other images.

Based on the dynamically picked multi-workers mode, provide the global
view as a graf with its MP/MT state synchronization as the following:

* use globally shared locking info also containing global layers view
  for MP-workers. With the shared global view state we can no longer
  use local locking objects individual for each task.
* if cannot use multi-process workers, like when executing it via
  Mistral by monkey patched eventlet greenthreads, choose threadinglock
  and multi-threads-safe standard dictionary in the shared class
  namespace to store the global view there
* if it can do MP, pick processlock also containing a safe from data
  races Manager().dict() as the global view shared among cooperating OS
  processes.
* use that global view in a transparent fashion, provided by a special
  classmethod proxying access to the internal state shared for workers.

Ultimately, all that optimizes:

* completion time
* re-fetching of the already processed layers
* local deduplication of layers
* the amount of outbound HTTP requests to registries
* if-layer-exists and other internal logic check executed against the
  in-memory cache firstly.

As layers locking and unlocking becomes a popular action, reduce the
noise of the debug messages it produces.

Closes-bug: #1847225
Related-bug: #1844446

Change-Id: Ie5ef4045b7e22c06551e886f9f9b6f22c8d4bd21

commit_message:
Remove container build timeout default to 3 hours

This removes the 7200s (2 hour) timeout from the container build
job. This means it will inherit from tripleo-ci-base which has
3 hour timeout. As in related bug, the master container build push
times out and blocks promotions.

Change-Id: I1de172073613d07fee21cb6a19d1382866dec11c
Related-Bug: 1857884

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-17 01:20:39.000000000', 'message': 'Eliminate race in CancelUpdateTest

The purpose of this test is to ensure we can rollback an in-progress
Server resource with attached ports. However, by cancelling immediately
we create a race whereby the stack may be rolled back before we have
even started updating the stack, in which case we are not testing the
behaviour we actually care about. Inserting a delay gives Heat enough
time to process the Port and start updating the Server before we cancel
the update.

In some circumstances this could also trigger a race within Heat,
whereby the rollback traversal would not block, but the update traversal
would retrigger it anyway. This resulted in the stack rollback being
marked COMPLETE multiple times, which could also lead to errors in
deleting the old raw_template after it had already been removed. The
latter have been fixed by separate patches. The race itself should be
addressed separately.

Change-Id: I3f9db686c31659437ff4797555e6608986946572
Task: 37199
'}, {'created': '2019-10-17 01:47:12.000000000', 'message': 'Eliminate race in CancelUpdateTest

In some circumstances this could also trigger a race within Heat,

would retrigger it anyway. This resulted in the stack rollback being
marked COMPLETE multiple times, which could also lead to errors in
deleting the old raw_template after it had already been removed. The
latter have been fixed by separate patches. The race itself should be
addressed separately.

Change-Id: I3f9db686c31659437ff4797555e6608986946572
