'}, {'created': '2019-08-15 10:14:45.000000000', 'message': "Introduce scope_types in Admin Actions

oslo.policy introduced the scope_type feature which can
control the access level at system-level and project-level.
 - https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/user/usage.html#setting-scope
 - http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/queens/system-scope.html

There are two type of scope:
1. 'system': policy with 'system' scope means user with
'system-scoped' token have permission to access otherwise not.
This scope type can be applied to API policies which need
access permission at system level.

2. 'project': policy with 'project' scope means user with
'project-scoped' token have permission to access.
This scope type can be applied to API policies which need
access permission at project level.

Any policy need permission for both scope 'system' and 'project'
can be added with both scope, for example: scope_type['system', 'project']

This commit introduce scope_type for Admin Actions API policies.

All the Admin Actions policy are scopped as 'system' because
nova services operation should not be given access to
project scopped token.

Also adds the test case with scope_type enabled and verify we
pass and fail the policy check with expected context.

commit_message:
Introduce scope_types in Admin Actions

oslo.policy introduced the scope_type feature which can
control the access level at system-level and project-level.
 - https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/user/usage.html#setting-scope
 - http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/queens/system-scope.html

Appropriate scope_type for nova case:
- https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ussuri/approved/policy-defaults-refresh.html#scope

This commit introduce scope_type for Admin Actions API policies.

All the Admin Actions policy are scopped as 'system' because
nova services operation should not be given access to
project scopped token.

Also adds the test case with scope_type enabled and verify we
pass and fail the policy check with expected context.

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh
Change-Id: I6d43cbe6dd32e17eda99a72699953b83b4e556bb

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-26 17:27:23.000000000', 'message': 'translation: drop babel extractor definitions

babel extractors are now registered via python entry points,
so there is no need to declare babel extractors in babel configs.

This change is important to make translation work in Django 2.2.
django-babel does not work with Django 2.2 and looks unmaintained
for over two years. The horizon team is thinking to switch the extractor
to enmerkar (a fork of django-babel) to make extraction of translation
string work again near future. It is important to drop the extractor
definition to make the transition smooth.

Change-Id: I5eb8b97475e1e277426a112f33212f78bb2295c6
'}]
commit_message:
translation: drop babel extractor definitions

babel extractors are now registered via python entry points,
so there is no need to declare babel extractors in babel configs.

This change is important to make translation work in Django 2.2.
django-babel does not work with Django 2.2 and looks unmaintained
for over two years. The horizon team is thinking to switch the extractor
to enmerkar (a fork of django-babel) to make extraction of translation
string work again near future. It is important to drop the extractor
definition to make the transition smooth.

Change-Id: I5eb8b97475e1e277426a112f33212f78bb2295c6

commit_message:
translation: drop babel extractor definitions

babel extractors are now registered via python entry points,
so there is no need to declare babel extractors in babel configs.

This change is important to make translation work in Django 2.2.
django-babel does not work with Django 2.2 and looks unmaintained
for over two years. The horizon team is thinking to switch the extractor
to enmerkar (a fork of django-babel) to make extraction of translation
string work again near future. It is important to drop the extractor
definition to make the transition smooth.

Change-Id: I0c3efb65e75e62212b9c5fc0cd759271111b5956

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-19 11:46:12.000000000', 'message': 'Adds peer persistence feature to HPE 3PAR driver

First attempt at a naive implementation for Peer Persistence volumes in the
HPE 3PAR driver for Cinder.

This is a cleaned-up version of a patch we are currently using on a
standalone Cinder installation (non-OpenStack). This means that the basic
functionality of being able to create cinder volumes with peer persistence
has been validated. However, a multitude of tests will be required in order
to merge this functionality upstream.

A first attempt at listing the tests to be executed:

- Validation of the "replication:peer_persistence" setting
- Double-check implementation/configuration of peerpersistent volumes
- Validate creation of peerpersistent volumes when one 3PAR instance is
  unavailable
- Validate automatic fail-over of an existing peerpersistent volume when
  a 3PAR instance goes offline
- Validate manual fail-over of a peerpersistent volumes
- Evaluate retype functionality for peerpersistent volumes

Changed:

- Fixed invalid variable name
- Resolved all Flake8 warnings
- Fixed one invalid if-clause when replication is not enabled
- Dict comprehension instead of dict constructor for PEP8

Change-Id: I559e14af76381e01e95deeaec4d0ffbfb4f975bb
'}]
commit_message:
Adds peer persistence feature to HPE 3PAR driver

First attempt at a naive implementation for Peer Persistence volumes in the
HPE 3PAR driver for Cinder.

This is a cleaned-up version of a patch we are currently using on a
standalone Cinder installation (non-OpenStack). This means that the basic
functionality of being able to create cinder volumes with peer persistence
has been validated. However, a multitude of tests will be required in order
to merge this functionality upstream.

A first attempt at listing the tests to be executed:

- Validation of the "replication:peer_persistence" setting
- Double-check implementation/configuration of peerpersistent volumes
- Validate creation of peerpersistent volumes when one 3PAR instance is
  unavailable
- Validate automatic fail-over of an existing peerpersistent volume when
  a 3PAR instance goes offline
- Validate manual fail-over of a peerpersistent volumes
- Evaluate retype functionality for peerpersistent volumes

Changed:

- Fixed invalid variable name
- Resolved all Flake8 warnings
- Fixed one invalid if-clause when replication is not enabled
- Dict comprehension instead of dict constructor for PEP8

Change-Id: I559e14af76381e01e95deeaec4d0ffbfb4f975bb

Thanks Pallav for adding the tests. 

This test is just verifying the configuration value and does not make as integration tests. This can be added in keystone as a unit or functional tests.  

If you have any integration scenario on keystone side then yoou can propose.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2019-12-18 21:49:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Big +1 for adding unit tests on keystone side instead.
As https://martinfowler.com/articles/practical-test-pyramid.html higher tests(tempest in this case) take time and money.
It is better to have lower tests(unit tests) as https://testing.googleblog.com/2015/04/just-say-no-to-more-end-to-end-tests.html'}, {'account_id': 23467, 'date': '2019-12-18 22:04:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Ghanshyam, Ohmichi for the review.  I've a question here.
In any environment, the max_request_body_size config value could with any value in keystone.conf and post deployment we can verify it by sending bigger data that’s define in configuration and this validation can be done during the tempest run to verify the security (Denial Of Service attack) because not all are running unit/functional tests post deployment."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-18 22:28:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Thanks Ghanshyam, Ohmichi for the review.  I've a question here.
 > In any environment, the max_request_body_size config value could
 > with any value in keystone.conf and post deployment we can verify
 > it by sending bigger data that’s define in configuration and this
 > validation can be done during the tempest run to verify the
 > security (Denial Of Service attack) because not all are running
 > unit/functional tests post deployment.

You can write the unit tests for that by changing the config value (you can do it via config fixture) and try the API request and see they behave. That way you can check configuration is being honoured by keystone API or not. It should be fast-fail from keystone so you do not need to perform the API operation and can mock it."}, {'account_id': 23467, 'date': '2019-12-18 23:21:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > Thanks Ghanshyam, Ohmichi for the review.  I've a question here.

 > they behave. That way you can check configuration is being honoured

Hi Ghanshyam, Ohmichi, Per PS https://review.opendev.org/#/c/144697/ max_request_body_size unit test was removed from keystone. Do you think again we need to add it?"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-18 23:25:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > > Thanks Ghanshyam, Ohmichi for the review.  I've a question

 > > > In any environment, the max_request_body_size config value

 > Hi Ghanshyam, Ohmichi, Per PS https://review.opendev.org/#/c/144697/
 > max_request_body_size unit test was removed from keystone. Do you
 > think again we need to add it?

Thanks for the link, That explain that this config option has been removed from keystone conf and added under oslo.middleware.

oslo.middleware has the unit test for this - https://github.com/openstack/oslo.middleware/blob/8c7fa5bb105cdfd15376c6b1f42ef1383b7cb3eb/oslo_middleware/tests/test_sizelimit.py#L77"}, {'account_id': 23467, 'date': '2019-12-26 17:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

validation of configuration value already part of unit testing hence there is no need of this PS. Abandoning it.'}]

[{'created': '2019-12-11 07:48:48.000000000', 'message': 'Add test to validate identity max request body size limit

The aim of this PS is to add a test to validate identity api
max request body size limit feature. This test ensures that
any malicious oversized request gets blocked ensuring continued
availability of the component. For more details, pls refer
https://docs.openstack.org/security-guide/identity/checklist.html#check-identity-05-is-max-request-body-size-set-to-default-114688

Change-Id: I4ce1ee9bf07d125876d4fc18a494334740fae599
'}]
commit_message:
Add test to validate identity max request body size limit

The aim of this PS is to add a test to validate identity api
max request body size limit feature. This test ensures that
any malicious oversized request gets blocked ensuring continued
availability of the component. For more details, pls refer
https://docs.openstack.org/security-guide/identity/checklist.html#check-identity-05-is-max-request-body-size-set-to-default-114688

Change-Id: I4ce1ee9bf07d125876d4fc18a494334740fae599

commit_message:
Drop babel extractor definitions from babel config

Babel allows us to register babel extractors via entry points.
This means we no longer need to have extractor definitions in
each babel config files. All horizon plugins have copies of
babel-django.cfg and babel-djangojs.cfg now. By dropping the
extractor defintiions from babel config files, we can make
a potential migration from django-babel to enmerkar (and
we can also avoid more modifications of babel config files
even if more transition is required).

django-babel and enmerkar both define 'django' extractor
in the entry point, so we can drop it from babel-django.cfg.
This commit also registers 'angular' extractor, so we can drop
the extractor for AngularJS from babel-djangojs.cfg.

Change-Id: Icf93d4551bd3db1baa84c110f06dcc1c36e18b7e

The LSB codename is far more reliable in order of giving us the
name of the current series as ansible_distribution_version can
be inaccurate in the case of unreleased versions such as Buster
which would return "NA" for that variable.

subject: debian: move to installing from bintray
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-06 02:49:04.000000000', 'message': 'debian: move to installing from bintray

Bintray contains a single deb which works across all Debian variants
which means that it can support current operating systems and those
which have not been released yet too (i.e. buster).

Long term, it would probably be good for us to use pinning and then
install the bintray repo, but this will make things work for Buster
for now.

Change-Id: I1448417a3a3fda35a05214dc4117d482ab0d21fc
'}]
commit_message:
debian: move to installing from bintray

Bintray contains a single deb which works across all Debian variants
which means that it can support current operating systems and those
which have not been released yet too (i.e. buster).

Long term, it would probably be good for us to use pinning and then
install the bintray repo, but this will make things work for Buster
for now.

Change-Id: I1448417a3a3fda35a05214dc4117d482ab0d21fc

The value of `image_cache_manager_interval` is misleading because
when setting it 0, it does not default to the nova value (2400)
but to the oslo.service default of 60 seconds which can cause
a tremendous amount of load in an environment where shared storage
is being used (such as NFS) where every hypervisor will pull a list
of all instances every 60 seconds.

commit_message:
nova: stop configuring image_cache_manager_interval by default

The value of `image_cache_manager_interval` is misleading because
when setting it 0, it does not default to the nova value (2400)
but to the oslo.service default of 60 seconds which can cause
a tremendous amount of load in an environment where shared storage
is being used (such as NFS) where every hypervisor will pull a list
of all instances every 60 seconds.

Change-Id: I3495cbfc79d25f5fcce5553150daca16356b7bc0

commit_message:
Stop running map_cell0 all the time

This task is only necessary to run when upgrading to Cells V2 which
was in Newton.  It takes a large amount of time to run in environments
that have already been upgraded as it scans the entire instances
database.

Beyond Newton, this task is no longer necessary.

Change-Id: I3f2f2eded9d6eb0385cff51e8b74bd4e6a7e0f92

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-20 15:24:56.000000000', 'message': 'Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: Ia14bc6397a88f200277abc5485cab02eb3724e1b
'}]
commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: Ia14bc6397a88f200277abc5485cab02eb3724e1b

commit_message:
Remove nova.image.download.modules extension point

There has been no patches to continue to maintain this extension
point so this patch removes that extension point from Nova.

Change-Id: I4f5d9e3cee3e006ace19579962b73f0ea09ab904

commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: I96758527bbba9d8ec298867390b25be493f57789

commit_message:
Add librsvg2* to bindep and bindep env

76cbd2dbbb131224e73a4b7c4019c378d2bbaf20 added the docs
build requirement on sphinxcontrib-svg2pdfconverter which
needs the native rsvg-convert command. This change adds
the native package that provides that command to bindep.txt.
Also adds bindep env in tox.ini.

Change-Id: I72aa8695c058989b4a1aa62cbb5d5fda2ce348ad

commit_message:
Remove locks from privileged ip_lib module

Because of issue with pyroute2.NetNS objects running in
threads we needed to lock privileged ip_lib functions
which are using this object to workaround the problem.
For details please check [1].

This problem was solved in pyroute 0.5.5. Now as we are using
0.5.7 we don't need those locks anymore.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1811515

Change-Id: I37da4025b93c8032164b0c3f12f400ed0d77c1ab

'}, {'created': '2019-12-25 08:45:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add coordination support for devstack

This way we can test the service api later on gate

In order to use etcd in gate few changes were made:
* All identifiers must be byte type (group type, member id)
* Tooz has a built-in mechanizm for heartbeat no need to implement it
* Need to use eventlet monkey patch since etcd client uses blocking
  methods
* Services name must be identical to LAUNCH_OPTIONS used in cli
* Gate coordination url should be define with a schema of etcd+http
  which is the etcd gateway and works better then just etcd

Change-Id: I772651e33eada4a5c2149bfa867095c277eddeed
'}]
commit_message:
Add coordination support for devstack

This way we can test the service api later on gate

In order to use etcd in gate few changes were made:
* All identifiers must be byte type (group type, member id)
* Tooz has a built-in mechanizm for heartbeat no need to implement it
* Need to use eventlet monkey patch since etcd client uses blocking
  methods
* Services name must be identical to LAUNCH_OPTIONS used in cli
* Gate coordination url should be define with a schema of etcd+http
  which is the etcd gateway and works better then just etcd

Change-Id: I772651e33eada4a5c2149bfa867095c277eddeed

commit_message:
Remove version check for encoding

Virtualbmc is now Python 3 only, encoding for ET can be set to
unicode only.
Removing import sys from vbmc.py as it was used only for that
check.

Change-Id: I35ac19308337f9fb603efa5b8a3dc97aea234cbc

commit_message:
Enforce running tox with correct python version based on env

Since removing support for Python 2, we changed the basepython
value to 3.
This means that all the tox tests run with the default python
version available in the system.
This is not quite correct when running on environment such as
py36, py37 or py38, since they imply running with different
Python versions based on the environment.
To enforce the correct version we need to add the option
ignore_basepython_conflict available since tox 3.1.0 [0].

[0] https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-ignore_basepython_conflict

Change-Id: I142774a28ebb200c2e6212f41c5734d578c5abea

(1 comment)

> "deprecation" means a warning of future removal, but you remove it. Is your intention to drop check_message, right?

Right I don't think we don't need that. If you look at https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1339885

We are setting message already like:

 msg = _('Unable to get nova services list.')

And then the next line is checking ["Connection", "refused"]

exceptions.check_message(["Connection", "refused"], msg)

When msg is already set to XYZ, there is no way it would get string "Connection" or "refused".

exceptions.check_message(["Connection", "refused"], msg) evaluates to None and the exceptions are handled by exceptions.handle(self.request, msg)

(Pdb) l
 66 services = nova.service_list(self.tab_group.request)
 67 except Exception:
 68 msg = _('Unable to get nova services list.')
 69 from remote_pdb import RemotePdb; RemotePdb('127.0.0.1', 444).set_trace()
 70 exceptions.check_message(["Connection", "refused"], msg)
 71 -> exceptions.handle(self.request, msg)
 72 services = []
 73 return services
 74
 75
 76 class CinderServicesTab(tabs.TableTab):
(Pdb) exceptions.handle(self.request, msg)
<class 'horizon.exceptions.RecoverableError'> 

Either we remove the check_message or fix the exception.'}, {'account_id': 19521, 'date': '2019-04-15 04:34:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thank you for the reviews pengyuesheng and Akihiro Motoki. Really appreciated.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-04-16 03:02:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

This cannot be merged as of now. According to [1], some horizon plugins use the message you are dropping. At least manila-ui uses it. Could you clean up check_message usages in horizon plugins before dropping it? Until then, I put -2 to avoid accidental breakage of horizon plugins.


[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=check_message&i=nope&files=&repos='}, {'account_id': 19521, 'date': '2019-04-16 04:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Definitely, totally forgot to look at plugins. Sorry Akihiro. Will fix that.'}, {'account_id': 19521, 'date': '2019-04-16 04:58:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Can be found in manila-ui:

[manila-ui]$ egrep -r "exceptions.check_message"
manila_ui/dashboards/admin/share_snapshots/tables.py:            exceptions.check_message(["snapshots", "dependent"], msg % name)                                                                                                            
manila_ui/dashboards/admin/share_group_snapshots/tables.py:            exceptions.check_message(["snapshots", "dependent"], msg % name)                                                                                                      
manila_ui/dashboards/project/share_snapshots/tables.py:            exceptions.check_message(["snapshots", "dependent"], msg % name)                                                                                                          
manila_ui/dashboards/project/share_group_snapshots/tables.py:            exceptions.check_message(["snapshots", "dependent"], msg % name)'}, {'account_id': 19521, 'date': '2019-04-17 13:01:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

@Akihiro, Thank you so much for your time. After further review it seems that I have misunderstood the check_message function as it checks the original exception from Nova in the background against the keywords and returns message.

If that fails to raise an exception then exception.handle is called. I have a feeling we will never raise exception in the check messages, as if we shutdown nova services we can only get ERROR 503 and there is no Connection refused string.

Do you think it's possible to ever get that Connection refused? I was thinking about it and maybe we should simply close the bug as WON'T FIX?

https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/horizon/exceptions.py#L196

(Pdb) set(keywords)
{'refused', 'Connection'}
(Pdb) p set(str(exc_value).split(" "))
{'(HTTP', 'Error', '503)', 'Unknown'}
(Pdb) p message
'Unable to get nova services list.'
(Pdb) 

I don't think we will'}, {'account_id': 19521, 'date': '2019-04-18 05:54:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Can you review https://github.com/zerodayz/openstack/blob/master/changes/Change_652427.md#check_message-function I was checking check_message vs handle handling the tabs.py and I think the check_message could be removed. It doesnt handle anything and when I tried to raise exception within check_message it just made horizon fail completely. When using the handle everything was fine'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-04-19 08:09:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I don't oppose the change itself as I mentioned before. What do want me to review more by the URL you post? I put -2 just because it breaks other horizon plugins."}, {'account_id': 30250, 'date': '2019-04-23 12:20:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi @Akihiro, I have created the Depend-on patch in Manila UI https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655119/ will be doing testing, marked the patch as WiP, are there any other projects that are using check_message?

I am going to explore if the issue is in general with check_message or it is only in the horizon, since other projects are using the check_messages in a different way, and they don't use the other way at all."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-05-22 02:49:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

It would be nice to cover it, but it can be covered separately or you can defer the fix to StarlingX team.

exceptions.handle() is used in most cases consistently.
check_message() is a legacy which was introduced when exceptions
were not well classified. exceptions.handle() should cover all
common error scenarios and there is no role played by check_messages().
Let's clean up its usage and deprecate it for the future removal.

Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I545b6c666d13d39cf5287ccc7c972dc746faf2fb

commit_message:
Deprecate exceptions.check_message

exceptions.handle() is used in most cases consistently.
check_message() is a legacy which was introduced when exceptions
were not well classified. exceptions.handle() should cover all
common error scenarios and there is no role played by check_messages().
Let's clean up its usage and deprecate it for the future removal.

Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I545b6c666d13d39cf5287ccc7c972dc746faf2fb
Closes-Bug: #1339885

commit_message:
Fix devstack installation error in FT

This patch fixes a bug[1] that devstack installation failed
due to a failed installation of the library(confluent-kafka)
required by Ceilometer.

The bug occurs because patch[2] has been merged,
and librdkafka(v1.3.0) required by confluent-kafka(v1.3.0)
is not installed.
NOTE: apt command installs v0.11.3, so build install.

[1]
http://paste.openstack.org/show/787901/

[2]
https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/c99ab09bc44818b92fe86842f98f564d54783982

Change-Id: I39c0ca534ede603d32c220ddd0b850ff5f16431c

commit_message:
Add 'volume_attachment' to volume expected attributes

'volume_attachment' is a frequently used attribute when
listing volumes inside or outside cinder, considering
it already has been loaded from database [1], this patch
adds it to volume's expected attributes to improve
performance.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/0652085f23ba22f0a6335726d9f0f7018d4662ea/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L1926

Change-Id: I3be3c99f9317726fa3182f750b27690da3cdab83

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-23 12:04:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add librsvg2* to bindep

9aab525d4546931f81bed665261278e7fc5bbeb4 added the docs
build requirement on sphinxcontrib-svg2pdfconverter which
needs the native rsvg-convert command. This change adds
the native package that provides that command to bindep.txt.

Change-Id: Ief712996e5880e149bbeecc93dc1be5b886653ac
'}]
commit_message:
Add librsvg2* to bindep

9aab525d4546931f81bed665261278e7fc5bbeb4 added the docs
build requirement on sphinxcontrib-svg2pdfconverter which
needs the native rsvg-convert command. This change adds
the native package that provides that command to bindep.txt.

Change-Id: Ief712996e5880e149bbeecc93dc1be5b886653ac

commit_message:
add X.509 certificate check plugin for monasca-agent

We need this in order to monitor the internal TLS certificates. Since
backporting feature to stable/pike is not feasible, the next option is
to patch RPM.

Change-Id: I4e0e78bf3627e77f52f88e5de40f3f702e80f26c

when using the drop "action", this change updates that so we're adding
drop rules and appending them to the rule chain.

Change-Id: I5105c007d890ec98b34eafba3ab410bf9ba4f089
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-12-18 14:43:20.000000000', 'message': 'Change drop action

The new firewall rule action plugin was setting the rule state as absent
when using the drop "action", this change updates that so we're adding

Change-Id: I5105c007d890ec98b34eafba3ab410bf9ba4f089
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Change drop action

The new firewall rule action plugin was setting the rule state as absent
when using the drop "action", this change updates that so we're adding
drop rules and appending them to the rule chain.

Change-Id: I5105c007d890ec98b34eafba3ab410bf9ba4f089
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

indeed a very good idea:)"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-26 10:35:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Could have been done as two separate patches, but otherwise LGTM'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-11-27 13:59:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Did you see my message at:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/011053.html

Quoted below:
"1) Are there even enough people around for these to be advisors?

2) What is going to happen with artifacts of Operations Docs SIG:
https://review.opendev.org/#/q/project:openstack/arch-design - no real
change since 1 year.

https://review.opendev.org/#/q/project:openstack/operations-guide has a
bit more activity.

What will happen with these two documents if the Operation Docs SIG
becomes advisory state?

Should we retire the repos and delete the content?

I don't know whether the other SIGS own any deliverables, where we need
to discuss what to do with them."


I'm -1 since advisory role and artifacts do not go together for me. So, I'm no opposing this change, I just think it's not ready yet.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-11-27 17:42:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Thanks Rico for new proposal and tag, It will really help to understand the SIG current status. 

I agree with Thierry that we can separate it in two patches: 
1. define the new tags in detail
2. propose the new tags to applicable SIG.  

I asked few questions about 'advisory' tag in ML-  
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/011215.html"}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2019-11-27 18:18:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

You explain the statuses in your mail. Maybe it would be good to add that explanation somewhere in this yaml, too.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-11-28 04:37:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Did you see my message at:
 > 
 > http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/011053.html
 > 
 > Quoted below:
 > "1) Are there even enough people around for these to be advisors?
 > 
 > 2) What is going to happen with artifacts of Operations Docs SIG:
 > https://review.opendev.org/#/q/project:openstack/arch-design - no
 > real
 > change since 1 year.
 > 
 > https://review.opendev.org/#/q/project:openstack/operations-guide
 > has a
 > bit more activity.
 > 
 > What will happen with these two documents if the Operation Docs SIG
 > becomes advisory state?

Yes, I think both of those questions should be answered by Operation Docs SIG members directly. That's why I kind of waiting for people from that SIG to jump into that ML.
 > 
 > Should we retire the repos and delete the content?
 > 
 > I don't know whether the other SIGS own any deliverables, where we
 > need
 > to discuss what to do with them."
 > 
 > 
 > I'm -1 since advisory role and artifacts do not go together for me.
 > So, I'm no opposing this change, I just think it's not ready yet.
That is a reasonable concern'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-11-28 04:49:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Thanks Rico for new proposal and tag, It will really help to
 > understand the SIG current status.
 > 
 > I agree with Thierry that we can separate it in two patches:
 > 1. define the new tags in detail
 > 2. propose the new tags to applicable SIG.
That will be nice thing to do indeed, I currently put those in SIG guideline, but sounds like should put in to reference under governance-sigs as well https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695366/

It's up to chairs from each SIG to help us know what's current status. 
For API SIG status. Always nice to see SIG play active role to reach out, will ping api sig chairs to see what's their idea for this"}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-11-28 06:41:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Let me add Sean and Chris as Operations Docs chairs to answer my questions about the repos.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-11-29 15:04:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Sorry, I haven't been following this. Can you explain what "advisory" status means for a SIG and why it applies here?'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-12-06 10:52:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

SIG statuses are defined at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/696456/

TL;DR is that we need a status between "active" (where newcomers can expect the SIG to hold meetings and have cycle objectives) and "abandoned"/"complete" (where the SIG no longer exists).

SIGs in advisory mode are staying around to give advice when prompted, but are not actively driving new things in the coming cycle (and are not meeting regularly). They traditionally only hold office hours.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-12-13 04:13:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Sorry, I haven't been following this. Can you explain what
 > "advisory" status means for a SIG and why it applies here?

This is merged. So check that out:) https://governance.openstack.org/sigs/reference/sig-status.html'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-12-13 04:14:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

pinging SIG chairs again for asking their feedbacks'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-13 14:23:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Comments inline, but I then re-read the description of advisory. So while some of these groups are still "active" in doing different things, I think their current state does match what was decided on for "advisory".

I'm a little concerned about the perception some will have if something is not listed as active, but I guess it does seem accurate.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-12-13 15:16:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

the "advisory" tag does not say anything about repos, so I remove my -1. I still think keeping the repos with outdated published content out is a bad idea if nobody is actively working on overhauling them (that's for me the state of adviserary).'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-13 16:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Tag status for SIGs and update SIG chair

This patch propose to update status tags. You can check [1] for more status
information.

Also update Resource Management SIG chair list.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/sigs/reference/sig-status.html

Change-Id: I5d9e844758fa84a3491ba22f64f83769a0d8cffe

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-20 21:15:18.000000000', 'message': 'Add cross-cell resize policy rule and enable in API

This adds the "compute:servers:resize:cross_cell" policy
rule which is now used in the API to determine if a resize
or cold migrate operation can be performed across cells.

The check in the API is based on:

- The policy check passing for the request.
- The minimum nova-compute service version being high
  enough across all cells to perform a cross-cell resize.

If either of those conditions fail a traditional same-cell
resize will be performed.

A docs stub is added here and will be fleshed out in an
upcoming patch.

Implements blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: Ie8a0f79a3b16e02b7a34a1b81f547013a3d88996
'}, {'created': '2019-02-20 21:51:51.000000000', 'message': 'Add cross-cell resize policy rule and enable in API

This adds the "compute:servers:resize:cross_cell" policy
rule which is now used in the API to determine if a resize
or cold migrate operation can be performed across cells.

The check in the API is based on:

- The policy check passing for the request.
- The minimum nova-compute service version being high
  enough across all cells to perform a cross-cell resize.

If either of those conditions fail a traditional same-cell
resize will be performed.

A docs stub is added here and will be fleshed out in an
upcoming patch.

Implements blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: Ie8a0f79a3b16e02b7a34a1b81f547013a3d88996

commit_message:
Add cross-cell resize policy rule and enable in API

This adds the "compute:servers:resize:cross_cell" policy
rule which is now used in the API to determine if a resize
or cold migrate operation can be performed across cells.

The check in the API is based on:

- The policy check passing for the request.
- The minimum nova-compute service version being high
  enough across all cells to perform a cross-cell resize.

If either of those conditions fail a traditional same-cell
resize will be performed.

A docs stub is added here and will be fleshed out in an
upcoming patch.

Implements blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: Ie8a0f79a3b16e02b7a34a1b81f547013a3d88996

subject: Implement cleanup_instance_network_on_host for neutron API

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-12-03 19:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build SUCCESSFUL (check pipeline).

- pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered http://52.27.155.124/62/697162/1/check/pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered/446274a/ : SUCCESS in 22m 15s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-03 22:00:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As predicted shelve offload isn't happy with this:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/4c7c39fee6934f78b525edc6bb4973cd/log/job-output.txt#30310

The problem is when unshelving the instance we try to update the port binding to point at the new host and that fails because the binding isn't found as there was only one and we deleted it during shelve offload:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/4c7c39fee6934f78b525edc6bb4973cd/log/controller/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz#20437

Dec 03 20:05:33.491386 ubuntu-bionic-rax-ord-0013195739 nova-compute[16648]: INFO nova.network.neutronv2.api [None req-d42df3fa-409b-47d4-b220-4a4ad54812f7 tempest-ServersNegativeTestJSON-1628792181 tempest-ServersNegativeTestJSON-1628792181] [instance: 66a4df4b-021d-42db-9961-c182f58b5709] Updating port 32ca5ab5-2770-4790-809b-f00f6c9f7447 with attributes {'binding:host_id': 'ubuntu-bionic-rax-ord-0013195739', 'device_owner': 'compute:nova'}

Dec 03 20:05:33.844004 ubuntu-bionic-rax-ord-0013195739 nova-compute[16648]: DEBUG neutronclient.v2_0.client [None req-d42df3fa-409b-47d4-b220-4a4ad54812f7 tempest-ServersNegativeTestJSON-1628792181 tempest-ServersNegativeTestJSON-1628792181] Error message: {"NeutronError": {"type": "PortNotFound", "message": "Port 32ca5ab5-2770-4790-809b-f00f6c9f7447 could not be found.", "detail": ""}} {{(pid=16648) _handle_fault_response /usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/neutronclient/v2_0/client.py:259}}

Dec 03 20:05:33.850677 ubuntu-bionic-rax-ord-0013195739 nova-compute[16648]: ERROR nova.network.neutronv2.api [None req-d42df3fa-409b-47d4-b220-4a4ad54812f7 tempest-ServersNegativeTestJSON-1628792181 tempest-ServersNegativeTestJSON-1628792181] [instance: 66a4df4b-021d-42db-9961-c182f58b5709] Unable to update binding details for port 32ca5ab5-2770-4790-809b-f00f6c9f7447: neutronclient.common.exceptions.PortNotFoundClient: Port 32ca5ab5-2770-4790-809b-f00f6c9f7447 could not be found.

File "/opt/stack/nova/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py", line 3438, in _update_port_binding_for_instance

So maybe the cleanup method should only delete a port binding if there is more than one binding for the same port?'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-03 22:01:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Alternatively, we could just have the shelve offload code not call cleanup_instance_network_on_host if using neutron since it was a no-op before and is problematic now since the shelve/unshelve case doesn't use multiple port bindings."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-03 22:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-12-03 22:37:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This implements the cleanup_instance_network_on_host method
in the neutron API which will delete port bindings for the
given instance and the given host, similar to how
setup_networks_on_host works when teardown=True and the
instance.host does not match the host provided to that method.

This allows removing the hacks in the
_confirm_snapshot_based_resize_delete_port_bindings and
_revert_snapshot_based_resize_at_dest methods.

commit_message:
Implement cleanup_instance_network_on_host for neutron API

This implements the cleanup_instance_network_on_host method
in the neutron API which will delete port bindings for the
given instance and the given host, similar to how
setup_networks_on_host works when teardown=True and the
instance.host does not match the host provided to that method.

This allows removing the hacks in the
_confirm_snapshot_based_resize_delete_port_bindings and
_revert_snapshot_based_resize_at_dest methods.

Change-Id: Iff8194c868580facb1cc81b5567d66d4093c5274

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-15 23:10:45.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add negative test to delete server during cross-cell resize claim

This adds a test based on review feedback [1] to see what happens
if the server is deleted from the source cell while a cross-cell
resize is claiming resources on the target host in the target cell.
The test ensures that the server is deleted from both the source
and target cell databases and volume attachments are cleaned up.

The test does expose a latent bug in the MigrationTask.rollback
code which moves the source node allocations, held by the migration
consumer, to the now-deleted instance. This is masked in part
by the SchedulerReportClient.move_allocations method not checking
that the target consumer has a generation so we POST /allocations
and re-create the instance allocations on the source node.

While in here I realized that the _cold_migrate method is not
gracefully handling InstanceNotFound when calling instance.refresh()
and that Migration.save() does not raise MigrationNotFound even if
the migration record is soft-deleted so a comment is left for that.
Those are really issues that should be dealt with separately.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/627890/60/nova/conductor/tasks/cross_cell_migrate.py@495

Change-Id: I32334afdbff2f17d6a1e98dfb29d393575e71080
TODO: open a bug for the latent issue during same-cell resize rollback

'}, {'created': '2019-11-03 17:16:41.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Add negative test to delete server during cross-cell resize claim

This adds a test based on review feedback [1] to see what happens
if the server is deleted from the source cell while a cross-cell
resize is claiming resources on the target host in the target cell.
The test ensures that the server is deleted from both the source
and target cell databases and volume attachments are cleaned up.

The test does expose a latent bug in the MigrationTask.rollback
code which moves the source node allocations, held by the migration
consumer, to the now-deleted instance. This is masked in part
by the SchedulerReportClient.move_allocations method not checking
that the target consumer has a generation so we POST /allocations
and re-create the instance allocations on the source node.

While in here I realized that the _cold_migrate method is not
gracefully handling InstanceNotFound when calling instance.refresh()
and that Migration.save() does not raise MigrationNotFound even if
the migration record is soft-deleted so a comment is left for that.
Those are really issues that should be dealt with separately.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/627890/60/nova/conductor/tasks/cross_cell_migrate.py@495

Related-Bug: #1848343

Change-Id: I32334afdbff2f17d6a1e98dfb29d393575e71080

commit_message:
WIP: Add negative test to delete server during cross-cell resize claim

This adds a test based on review feedback [1] to see what happens
if the server is deleted from the source cell while a cross-cell
resize is claiming resources on the target host in the target cell.
The test ensures that the server is deleted from both the source
and target cell databases and volume attachments are cleaned up.

The test does expose a latent bug in the MigrationTask.rollback
code which moves the source node allocations, held by the migration
consumer, to the now-deleted instance. This is masked in part
by the SchedulerReportClient.move_allocations method not checking
that the target consumer has a generation so we POST /allocations
and re-create the instance allocations on the source node.

While in here I realized that the _cold_migrate method is not
gracefully handling InstanceNotFound when calling instance.refresh()
and that Migration.save() does not raise MigrationNotFound even if
the migration record is soft-deleted so a comment is left for that.
Those are really issues that should be dealt with separately.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/627890/60/nova/conductor/tasks/cross_cell_migrate.py@495

Related-Bug: #1848343

Change-Id: I32334afdbff2f17d6a1e98dfb29d393575e71080

subject: Enable cross-cell resize in the nova-multi-cell job

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-03 15:11:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The problem is that devstack-tempest's run will override the devstack-base run which sets up devstack, it does this so the tempest jobs can setup devstack and then setup and run tempest. By my pre-run running the orchestrate-devstack role, it was running devstack twice. By removing that role from my pre-run, I'm running before the devstack-tempest run sets up devstack, hence the stack user permissions failure.

Without a hook into the devstack-tempest playbook I'd have to override and duplicate the devstack-tempest run, which I don't want to do since if that changes in tempest for some reason, it could be broken in our job and we wouldn't know why.

So for now, I'll probably just hack the legacy way of doing this by putting a variable in devstack to allow setting a policy rule in nova's policy.yaml until we have something more elegant."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-03 15:38:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-03 15:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

DBDuplicateEntry: (pymysql.err.IntegrityError) (1062, "Duplicate entry '4b9a5615-c534-4205-892b-947b8460c874-ubuntu-bionic-ovh-gra1-0005' for key 'PRIMARY'") [SQL: 'UPDATE ml2_port_bindings SET host=%(host)s, vif_type=%(vif_type)s, vif_details=%(vif_details)s WHERE ml2_port_bindings.port_id = %(ml2_port_bindings_port_id)s AND ml2_port_bindings.host = %(ml2_port_bindings_host)s'] [parameters: {'host': 'ubuntu-bionic-ovh-gra1-0005970038', 'vif_type': 'unbound', 'vif_details': '', 'ml2_port_bindings_port_id': '4b9a5615-c534-4205-892b-947b8460c874', 'ml2_port_bindings_host': 'ubuntu-bionic-ovh-gra1-0005970036'}]

This runs on ubuntu-bionic-ovh-gra1-0005970036. There is a port binding with this primary key constraint:

4b9a5615-c534-4205-892b-947b8460c874-ubuntu-bionic-ovh-gra1-0005

ml2_port_bindings_port_id = 4b9a5615-c534-4205-892b-947b8460c874

And we're trying to update a port binding for host ml2_port_bindings_host=ubuntu-bionic-ovh-gra1-0005970036 and it's complaining about ubuntu-bionic-ovh-gra1-0005 which is a substring of ubuntu-bionic-ovh-gra1-0005970036, is it possible the unique constraint is puking on the substring?'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-05-04 16:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Looking at the logs, we successfully spawn the instance on the dest host and then register the network-vif-plugged callback event on the dest host:

http://logs.openstack.org/56/656656/7/check/nova-multi-cell/489b1de/compute1/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz#_May_10_00_52_42_028541

May 10 00:52:42.028541 ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0006071080 nova-compute[17611]: DEBUG nova.compute.manager [None req-2e8d7e70-5fa0-4c47-a9c1-052f898f077a tempest-MigrationsAdminTest-2105702524 tempest-MigrationsAdminTest-2105702524] [instance: f07072db-e705-4222-814b-e1c3a3d66ce4] Preparing to wait for external event network-vif-plugged-06d6044c-50d5-4c0d-89d0-c6beca5658cf {{(pid=17611) prepare_for_instance_event /opt/stack/nova/nova/compute/manager.py:319}}

But I never see the event come into the dest host, I do see it on the source host:

http://logs.openstack.org/56/656656/7/check/nova-multi-cell/489b1de/controller/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz#_May_10_00_52_45_641705

May 10 00:52:45.641705 ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0006071002 nova-compute[29406]: WARNING nova.compute.manager [req-72e6c1aa-4fd8-48c0-91eb-9683b15a1964 req-c90b0ac5-be8f-42f7-810d-03a995a03162 service nova] [instance: f07072db-e705-4222-814b-e1c3a3d66ce4] Received unexpected event network-vif-plugged-06d6044c-50d5-4c0d-89d0-c6beca5658cf for instance with vm_state active and task_state resize_migrated.

So that means the API isn't routing the event properly to the dest host. It's routing to the source host because at this point, the instance mapping is still pointing at the source cell and the instance is pointing at the source host. But the migration_context should be in the source cell and point at the dest host and route there, so something isn't working in that code.

I do see this in the API logs when it gets the event from neutron:

May 10 00:52:45.629565 ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0006071002 devstack@n-api.service[19389]: DEBUG nova.compute.api [req-72e6c1aa-4fd8-48c0-91eb-9683b15a1964 req-c90b0ac5-be8f-42f7-810d-03a995a03162 service nova] Instance f07072db-e705-4222-814b-e1c3a3d66ce4 is migrating, copying events to all relevant hosts: {'ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0006071002', 'ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0006071080'} {{(pid=19390) _get_relevant_hosts /opt/stack/nova/nova/compute/api.py:5063}}

In this run, ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0006071080 is the dest host and ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0006071002 is the source host."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-10 20:35:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-05-10 23:24:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

It looks like test_revert_cold_migration is failing because on revert on the dest host we delete the active dest host port binding and then when we go to update the port's binding:host_id to point at the source host, it fails in neutron because the dest host port binding doesn't exist anymore, which seems like a bug in neutron (maybe it's trying to do some kind of cleanup and not handling the deleted dest host port binding gracefully). Anyway, the workaround is probably to just activate the source host port binding before deleting the dest host port binding like here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/594139/"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-22 14:43:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13: Patch Set 12 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-05-23 05:06:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-01 15:36:51.000000000', 'message': 'Enable cross-cell resize in the nova-multi-cell job

This changes the nova-multi-cell job to essentially
force cross-cell resize and cold migration. By "force"
I mean there is only one compute in each cell and
resize to the same host is disabled, so the scheduler
has no option but to move the server to the other cell.

This adds a new role to write the nova policy.yaml file
to enable cross-cell resize and a pre-run playbook so
that the policy file setup is done after devstack is
done stacking but before tempest runs.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: Ia4f3671c40e69674afc7a96b5d9b198dabaa4224

commit_message:
Enable cross-cell resize in the nova-multi-cell job

This changes the nova-multi-cell job to essentially
force cross-cell resize and cold migration. By "force"
I mean there is only one compute in each cell and
resize to the same host is disabled, so the scheduler
has no option but to move the server to the other cell.

This adds a new role to write the nova policy.yaml file
to enable cross-cell resize and a pre-run playbook so
that the policy file setup before tempest runs.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: Ia4f3671c40e69674afc7a96b5d9b198dabaa4224

commit_message:
Flesh out docs for cross-cell resize/cold migrate

This gives most of the high level information. I'm sure there
are more troubleshooting things we can add but those could come
later as they crop up.

The sequence diagram(s) will come in a separate change.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I13f07a2d45bf5b8584adc8aa079bae640cb5c470

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-21 01:10:40.000000000', 'message': 'Simplify FinishResizeAtDestTask event handling

Rather than copy the instance action event from the target
cell DB to the source cell DB when
_finish_snapshot_based_resize_at_dest fails on the dest host,
we can simply use the EventReporter context in conductor with
the source cell context and get the same event.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I8053765797f097859bf585459f4a00d31844708e

commit_message:
Simplify FinishResizeAtDestTask event handling

Rather than copy the instance action event from the target
cell DB to the source cell DB when
_finish_snapshot_based_resize_at_dest fails on the dest host,
we can simply use the EventReporter context in conductor with
the source cell context and get the same event.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I8053765797f097859bf585459f4a00d31844708e

commit_message:
Add sequence diagrams for cross-cell-resize

This tries to strike a balance between giving a useful high level
flow without injecting too much complex detail in each diagram.

For the more complicated resize diagram, I have used labels to
try and make clear which conductor task is performing an action.

For the less complicated confirm and revert diagrams, I add a
separator to show where the conductor task is orchestrating the
calls and provide a bit more detail into what each task is doing
since the calls to computes are minimal in those cases.

Part of blueprint cross-cell-resize

Change-Id: I27c549901a3359f106ba5d77aa6559397ee12a5d

commit_message:
image-uploader: allow an image without Labels to be uploaded

Some images, like grafana don't have Labels set; let's just set an empty
default if an image has no Labels and continue the upload.

Change-Id: I571af51db0d21226bc42dc21925384f0129cd581
Closes-Bug: #1857012
(cherry picked from commit 95b68c6d19119a022f94061ba98accc717ff6657)

messages:
[{'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2019-11-20 16:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15895, 'date': '2019-11-20 20:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

From what I see the devstack failures seems to be random. It really smells of a race condition in our tests in tempest'}, {'account_id': 30755, 'date': '2019-11-23 13:00:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-11-25 03:26:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30755, 'date': '2019-11-25 14:03:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30755, 'date': '2019-11-26 08:28:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2019-11-26 09:31:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2 Workflow-1

Please don't recheck. The jobs are unstable and for it to merge they need to pass twice in a row (check and gate). This is unlikely to happen.

If we want to make these voting again we need to make the jobs stable."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-12-25 08:22:19.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

If needed, we'll make these jobs voting again later (given that we fix jobs)"}]

subject: Dry run feature
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7700, 'name': 'Nikolay Mahotkin', 'email': 'nikolay.makhotkin@gmail.com', 'username': 'nmakhotkin'}, {'_account_id': 8731, 'name': 'Renat Akhmerov', 'email': 'renat.akhmerov@gmail.com', 'username': 'rakhmerov'}, {'_account_id': 9712, 'name': 'Dougal Matthews', 'email': 'dougal.matthews@canonical.com', 'username': 'dougal'}, {'_account_id': 15895, 'name': 'Adriano Petrich', 'email': 'apetrich@redhat.com', 'username': 'apetrich'}, {'_account_id': 21970, 'name': 'Andras Kovi', 'email': 'akovi@nokia.com', 'username': 'andras.kovi'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 27008, 'name': 'Vitalii Solodilov', 'email': 'Mcdkr@yandex.ru', 'username': 'mcdoker18'}, {'_account_id': 29124, 'name': 'Oleg Ovcharuk', 'email': 'vgvoleg@gmail.com', 'username': 'vgvoleg'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2019-07-10 23:02:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2019-07-11 14:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2019-07-11 20:08:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2019-07-11 23:26:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2019-07-17 11:07:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Thank you! Although this change seems ok, I would like to ask how useful/valid the base use case is. That is, to check the execution of the WF without executing actions. The problem I feel with the assumption that this can be done in any real workflows is that in most cases the edges from one task to the other will contain conditions. Also, the inputs and publish statements will require data to be present. As much as I would like to have this kind of functionality, it feels to be a blunt statement that this will be applicable in real world scenarios. Also, in most cases, the real challenge stems from the desire to be able to cover the possible branches of execution.
My humble opinion is that we shouldn't try to support this use case as it introduces maintenance cost with complexity and the power yield of this feature is negligible in most cases. So, in fact, I'd vote -2 but I'm open to discussion, of course."}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2019-07-18 15:28:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Thank you! Although this change seems ok, I would like to ask how
 > useful/valid the base use case is. That is, to check the execution
 > of the WF without executing actions. The problem I feel with the
 > assumption that this can be done in any real workflows is that in
 > most cases the edges from one task to the other will contain
 > conditions. Also, the inputs and publish statements will require
 > data to be present. As much as I would like to have this kind of
 > functionality, it feels to be a blunt statement that this will be
 > applicable in real world scenarios. Also, in most cases, the real
 > challenge stems from the desire to be able to cover the possible
 > branches of execution.
 > My humble opinion is that we shouldn't try to support this use case
 > as it introduces maintenance cost with complexity and the power
 > yield of this feature is negligible in most cases. So, in fact, I'd
 > vote -2 but I'm open to discussion, of course.

Andras, thanks for you reply. The main idea is to provide the opportunity to run any tasks without any impact to any external system. If anyone wants to run a task in dry run mode, he should be sure that action under this task supports it.
So this patch is only an instrument and people who want to use this feature should implement this behavior in their actions. So, if any action in normal mode should return some value, the dry run mode should return some stub and so on. 
For now, I just want to provide an instrument for this, maybe later it would be great to extend openstack actions and std (I am not sure if std actions should be changed to support this or not)"}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2019-07-29 18:41:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

> Andras, thanks for you reply. The main idea is to provide the
 > opportunity to run any tasks without any impact to any external
 > system. If anyone wants to run a task in dry run mode, he should be
 > sure that action under this task supports it.
 > So this patch is only an instrument and people who want to use this
 > feature should implement this behavior in their actions. So, if any
 > action in normal mode should return some value, the dry run mode
 > should return some stub and so on.
 > For now, I just want to provide an instrument for this, maybe later
 > it would be great to extend openstack actions and std (I am not
 > sure if std actions should be changed to support this or not)

Thanks Oleg, I really appreciate your feedback. Adding 'programmatic' features to the language is good on one hand but it also means code is added to the workflow. That code can fail and is practically a mock so it is up to the developer to recreate the behavior of the real world. I still have doubts about how this can be used in real life workflows. I'm not against adding it and if it works for your use cases, it's great."}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2019-12-07 17:32:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-12-10 05:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-12-25 05:01:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-12-25 05:45:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}]

commit_message:
Dry run feature

Now it is possible to execute tasks in dry-run mode, so instead of 'run'
action method 'test' will be executed. It could be configured
for a single task or for a whole workflow in task-defaults section.

Change-Id: I9b50bb40d2f1fc883f32406f4bc11f03a15f0a70
Implements: blueprint mistral-dry-run
Signed-off-by: Oleg Ovcharuk <vgvoleg@gmail.com>

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Zaqar is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/

Change-Id: I0fde9d2f16f3cc77be3d4cab482fa0fb7ab9e7fc

commit_message:
Delete removed dashboard panel when upgrading

The old v1 dashboard panel has been removed, when upgrading from an
older version we need to remove the symbolic link for it in order to
avoid horizon from failing.

Change-Id: I383884aa100fd983e1087d7458396f8053414d55

commit_message:
WIP: integration tests: Install avconv

avconv was previously installed by devstack-gate hooks,
but it does not work after zuul v3 migration.
The logic was migrated from scripts under tools/gate/integration.

Change-Id: I2b8f89dc60db2b0e513d6b303321a2adafa7cd04

commit_message:
Fix pacemaker firewall rules

We switched to ansible for firewall rule management but the pacemaker
file wasn't properly converted.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700472/
Change-Id: Id7f2942436565015211dcfa19fe95adb454c667e
Closes-Bug: #1857356

commit_message:
k8s_fedora: Bump up default kube_tag to v1.15.7

Also bump up cloud_provider_tag to v1.15.0.

This is the common supported version in Fedora Atomic (now EOL) when
`use_podman=true` label is not supplied.

Task: 37817
Story: 2005380

Change-Id: I4afaf159eaf2d2ff75bd3abec4137257e0daa8f2
Signed-off-by: Bharat Kunwar <brtknr@bath.edu>
(cherry picked from commit 9e3be39dd5909c9b8c3e2d454f4c1269319ed583)

commit_message:
Handle null enabled_networks and role_networks

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699502/ patch caused
issue in undercloud-minion job where role_networks is null,
this patch fixes it by handling null values, also this patch adds
undercloud-minion voting job to catch such failures in future.

Change-Id: Ibb07a0b003bffdd1c76ff5816dccdadecb684db4

commit_message:
Ensure network leftovers without kuryrnet CRD obj are deleted

This patch ensures that network leftovers without kuryrnet CRD
object associated (caused by crash/restart of the kuryr-controller
at an unfortunate time) are also handled by the cleanup thread
triggered at the kuryr-controller restart.

Change-Id: Id1d036b80438b21a100be12282058b995c36d2c3
Closes-Bug: 1856843

commit_message:
Ensure LB member is removed upon pod removal

When pods that run on host network and are pointed by a svc
are removed, the removal of the load balancer member is
ignored, as right now the name of the pod is not taken into
account on the decision of which members to delete, and the
current attributes checked are pod ip and port, which remains
the same. This commit fixes the issue by ensuring the
pod name is also checked.

Closes-Bug: 1857354
Change-Id: I44f7f76da692ac3002c91a1420969584b4d31cbd

commit_message:
Move some common tasks to step 1

These tasks in deploy-steps-tasks.yaml currently run at every step, but
they only actually need to run once. This patch moves them to
deploy-steps-tasks-step-1.yaml so that they are only run at step1 and do
not need to be skipped at every later step.

Change-Id: Ib64d1969c5dff3901829583fc2db2f6e2a3acbb3
(cherry picked from commit af88862d9b27657160c47c9bab249af246af76f8)

commit_message:
Fix proxy issue for k8s fedora drivers

Due to the big changes recently to support k8s rolling upgrade, a
regression issue was introduced which is broken the proxy function
for image downloading. This patch fixes it for both fedor atomic
driver and fedora coreos driver.

Task: 37784
Story: 2007005

Change-Id: I11113d69629e1a97a58e5270f67c7404292b45c3
(cherry picked from commit ad2ef4962c83a42692fb0662e4eac2484fd7cf83)

commit_message:
Gate on octavia-v2-dsvm-tls-barbican

At the Shanghai PTG, members of the Barbican and Octavia teams seemed to
agree that job octavia-v2-dsvm-tls-barbican could be made voting in both
projects. The job has proven to be quite stable over time [1].

The patch that make the job voting in Barbican is [2].

[1] http://zuul.openstack.org/builds?job_name=octavia-v2-dsvm-tls-barbican
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697640/

Change-Id: I1c7b123e4708a614aaa86ec3d41dade7f34d5f3f

commit_message:
Stop using six library

Since we've dropped support for Python 2.7, it's time to look at
the bright future that Python 3.x will bring and stop forcing
compatibility with older versions.
This patch removes the six library from requirements, not
looking back.

Hmmmm, I was expecting this to be attribute on the node in the graph, not a attribute of the task itself, do u think making it on the node in the graph (but not on the task itself) makes sense?

For example:

https://github.com/networkx/networkx/blob/master/networkx/classes/graph.py#L408

When add_node is called an 'attr_dict' can be provided, this could be used to store this ANY/ALL attribute in the graph itself (without having to have it on the task object itself). That feels more appropriate to me, what do u think?"}, {'account_id': 14819, 'date': '2015-08-04 21:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14819, 'date': '2015-08-04 21:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think the decider feature needs to be thought through a bit more as far as whether it's addressing the use case properly or whether we're adding complexity that is potentially detrimental to the usability and understandability of taskflow...  I think this isn't the first edge case I've seen with the decider feature, there was a problem that the octavia team was running in to as well best as I can remember"}, {'account_id': 14819, 'date': '2015-08-24 21:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Min Pae, thanks for review. Here is use case I try to cover: I need to implement in some way if/else in the terms of TaskFlow, decider functions looks very promising, but the problem is there is no ability to say taskflow is there really required to have all predecessors in success state, or some of them could never be executed at all. For example, I need to make request to scheduler if there no destination host, or verify if it fits requirements or not, then i want to send request to destination, no mather which of theese branches were executed. This patch addresses this problem. If it seems rare I would like to get more feedback from you, how to make it better and simpler. 
thanks, Timofey.'}, {'account_id': 14819, 'date': '2015-08-25 06:23:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-08-25 07:35:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified+1

commit_message:
Method set_required_parents introduced for GraphFlow class

To allow user specify whether it's required that all
predecessors to be executed successfully or not new method for
GraphFlow class was introduced.

Closes-bug: #1480907

Change-Id: Ic9f8dd58c1265a85a822e79e9ccf23f5a7f018d2

commit_message:
Stop using six library

Since we've dropped support for Python 2.7, it's time to look at
the bright future that Python 3.x will bring and stop forcing
compatibility with older versions.
This patch removes the six library from requirements, not
looking back.

Change-Id: I4b60638bb0268e5d1cf54fdf7d61964082536f4f

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-12-10 19:00:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-12-10 19:02:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-10 22:33:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

It's not clear whether pep8 is actually running [1]...

 2019-12-10 19:05:57.454122 | ubuntu-bionic |   pep8: skipped tests
 2019-12-10 19:05:57.454171 | ubuntu-bionic |   congratulations :)

...because I've seen that message before and eventually discovered it was spurious (and the tests *were* in fact running). To get rid of that message, we need ignore_basepython_conflict=True in tox.ini.

Given that we surely need a recheck here (afaict this was an infra snafu, not a real fail) I think it's worth doing that before we proceed.

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/6d04e3621c224f4e945e2cf18690017a/log/job-output.txt#453"}, {'account_id': 27822, 'date': '2019-12-24 06:27:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}]

Vishal Manchanda wrote:

> Thanks for the patch but the same changes are purposed in [1] in a
> better way. So kindly abandon it. [1]

This statement is a bit confusing.
It does not necessarily mean a better way.

When it was proposed, this change made sense.
However, the effort of dropping python2.7 is ongoing and
we can cover it both in a single change.
That's the reason we approved 696952."}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-12-05 13:28:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

yeah exactly."}, {'account_id': 27822, 'date': '2019-12-24 06:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Bump the openstackdocstheme extension to 1.20

Some options are now automatically configured by the version 1.20:
- project
- html_last_updated_fmt
- latex_engine
- latex_elements
- version
- release.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-20 17:55:20.000000000', 'message': 'Correct invalid jinja set

This change corrects an issue with the jinja expression at the
top of the file which is resulting in a stacktrace when the
set attempts to update an object of the same name, which results
in a none type.

This change also updates the jinja expression at the top of the
file making it more legible.

Change-Id: Ia3334c5d8a20bb3c0bc721a266a09b6c01fe7c4d
Closes-Bug: #1856918
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Correct invalid jinja set

This change corrects an issue with the jinja expression at the
top of the file which is resulting in a stacktrace when the
set attempts to update an object of the same name, which results
in a none type.

This change also updates the jinja expression at the top of the
file making it more legible.

Change-Id: Ia3334c5d8a20bb3c0bc721a266a09b6c01fe7c4d
Closes-Bug: #1856918
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

subject: fix test failure
messages:
[{'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2019-06-21 00:49:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-06-21 06:31:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think it works, why you want to change the test path?

If you want to run stestr directly, you can use:

  stestr run networking_generic_switch.tests.unit.netmko

Note that you have to resolve all requirements by yourself.

Or just simply run:

  tox -e py36 -- networking_generic_switch.tests.unit.netmiko"}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2019-06-21 07:08:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I don't think it works, why you want to change the test path?
 >

 > 
 > stestr run networking_generic_switch.tests.unit.netmko
 > 
 > Note that you have to resolve all requirements by yourself.
 > 
 > Or just simply run:
 > 
 > tox -e py36 -- networking_generic_switch.tests.unit.netmiko

I think each test case should be able to run separately.

for example, I should be able to run  

python -munittest networking_generic_switch.tests.unit.netmiko.test_cisco3000

without messing with all of the error reports..."}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2019-06-21 07:09:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

sorry for the typo,

python -munittest networking_generic_switch.tests.unit.netmiko.test_cisco_300"}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-06-21 08:13:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This patch doesn't cover all unit tests, I think we'll need to setup a base test class for all unit tests."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-06-21 08:24:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

ah.. posting the wrong error log. I've updated bug description please have a look thanks."}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2019-12-24 06:11:51.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
fix test failure

test cases directly under tests/unit/netmiko are failed when running directly. this problem is due to the fact that some options are not correctly registered.

Change-Id: Ieb2acc895b670ad0732860acf5d53cfea34a2ee7
Closes-Bug: #1833634

commit_message:
use urljoin to form swift_url for swift backup driver

using "%s%s" % (url, project_id) has a problem when url is given without a
trailing forward slash. Use urljoin will correctly form swift-url.

Change-Id: I325519f90b1931de2b9496c0d599a0653ad6c93c

commit_message:
Add notes on the pxe template for aarch64

On verifying deployment on aarch64 bare metals, the linuxefi and
initrdefi are not available in grubaa64.efi, update doc to note
the potential change required on multi-architecture setup.

Change-Id: I92786eaed2c3bf6fb9f25672183bd9511e7a6e6e

commit_message:
Ensure LB sg update is retried when NP is enforced

In case an endpoint is not yet annotated with the lbaas
state, when a Network Policy enforcement is triggered,
the update of the lbaas SG is ignored, causing a security breach.
This commit fixes the issue by retrying the update of the sg.

Closes-bug: 1856842

Change-Id: I4ebb8d5da52ff2cee8970b061e31b3f391cacc1b

commit_message:
Stop using six library

Since we've dropped support for Python 2.7, it's time to look at
the bright future that Python 3.x will bring and stop forcing
compatibility with older versions.
This patch removes the six library from requirements, not
looking back.

Change-Id: Ib546f16965475c32b2f8caabd560e2c7d382ac5a

commit_message:
Incorrectly derives NeutronPhysnetNUMANodesMapping

This change is to derive the NeutronPhysnetNUMANodesMapping
parameter as dictionary instead of list.

Change-Id: I0715d9012bc50b7d0d6d555d9d8c7ba821a9b96f
Closes-Bug: #1856068
(cherry picked from commit c0771bf722dcd7d008a005e784e7b982131bca7a)
(cherry picked from commit efc53a84e25ec49eea9d97882e92d613e8180490)
(cherry picked from commit 515eb554b48312f16c26a0d67df261454ec45df3)

commit_message:
Remove fedora28 repo info

We don't support the fedora 28 bits anymore now that centos8 is on the
way.

Change-Id: Ib9a7582bf7521304f8931a64e2d4a23b971de1f1

commit_message:
Action plugin for timestamping a file

This change adds an action plugin called timestamp_file that will
check if a file exists on a remote system and copies it out of the
way so that a new version can be created. This plugin can be used to
ensure that logs aren't overwritten or some other file you want to keep
before modifying.

Change-Id: I699641f65f20c7c4814632eb380525843ebcba98

commit_message:
tripleo-keystone-resources: handle multiple roles per user

os_user_role module can only assign one role to a user.
If a user needs multiple roles, we need a filter to build a dict where
each key is a user with a list of the assigned roles.

Change-Id: I3aff5f25b90affceacdf95d0f2725ed740761b70

messages:
[{'account_id': 25395, 'date': '2018-02-09 08:26:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27248, 'date': '2018-02-20 12:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

DEFAULT_POOL should also be set required=True because the condition had LB and DEFAULT_POOL both being checked.'}, {'account_id': 25395, 'date': '2018-02-23 08:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> DEFAULT_POOL should also be set required=True because the condition
 > had LB and DEFAULT_POOL both being checked.

Do you mean that we can get LB ID from DEFAULT_POOL?'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-02-26 09:54:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This seems reasonable. I wonder if the original intention was to obtain the listener ID from the default pool ID somehow?'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-05-07 11:00:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi as we now migrated from Launchpad to StoryBoard ( https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/project_group/82 ), we needs to link from your patch to StoryBoard, as for how to provide the link, please reference `How to connect from Gerrit to StoryBoard` section in https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Heat-StoryBoard-Migration-Info
Please help to add those keys to your commit message. Thank you.'}, {'account_id': 25395, 'date': '2018-09-06 06:57:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> DEFAULT_POOL should also be set required=True because the condition
 > had LB and DEFAULT_POOL both being checked.

LB ID is required https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/master/octavia/api/v2/controllers/listener.py#L203-L205.

We can try to get lb id from default pool, if pool has no lb id, we will raise exception.'}, {'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2019-12-23 18:28:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 25395, 'date': '2019-12-24 00:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
